description:
Quite interesting decor for a bar!  

I think this place was Middle Eastern of something before it became a bar because of the architectural arches, layout and fabrics on the walls! 

Divey bar!

Pretty cool to drop by and have a drink!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Nice little bar. Cash only-- so be aware of that (but there is an ATM machine in there). Funky with a Arabic sort-of feel. The bartender when I was there, Simon, was nice and pretty attentive even though he was the only one working. 

Everyone - seriously EVERYONE - was getting martinis, so we got them as well.  They were good, the people watching was good, and it had a nice vibe. 

No TV, so no sports bar feel.  Just dark and funky.

I'd stop in for a drink again, if I have the cash :-)
author: Sharon V.

description:
This place doesn't pretend to be anything that it isn't.  They have no drink menu and don't want one.  I didn't have one but they are known for their martinis and drink-wise, not much else.  

Because this is in such a touristy area of Haight-Ashbury, there's a wide audience that come in and if you grab a seat at the bar, you can hear some pretty hilarious conversations as the bartender throws shade at everyone.  For example someone asked what whiskey drinks they have and he replies 'I dunno, whiskey and ice?' You have to have a sense of humor in this place, which I can tell from some of the reviews that people don't get it.  

I sat in here for a few drinks and the bartender did warm up to me.  You just have to know what you're getting yourself into.

I got a few whiskey drinks including old fashioneds.  The bartender made them strong!  I only needed a few to be knocked on my butt and heading home for the night.  Glad I picked this place off of Yelp to check out!
author: Brandon B.

description:
This bar has a TON of history, which I'll let you research on your own. Reasons to love it: 
1) dog friendly 
2) the bartender has a hella generous pour! 
3) fantastic martinis 
What more do you need?!
author: An S.

description:
What a cool, unique place where time's stood still. No TVs, cash only -- the bartender was even using the original cash register from like the 1940s. So of course I ordered an old fashioned. It was made well. But not like trendy craft cocktail well. Like old fashioned old fashioned well. The bartender chatted with regulars stopping by for a Sunday funday drink or three. One guy was drinking solo, in a cast thanks to a motorcycle accident. All good as he knew he had friends to keep his spirits up at Zam Zam.

There was a big old dog laying next to the bar. She was super sweet. And super tired. There's just a bit of magic to this place. You forget that Haight Street is now overrun by tourists when you get here, even though I was kind of a tourist myself (works trips to SF make me not a tourist, right?).
author: Will S.

description: You can count on here to be a nice calm place for a basic drink at any hour of the evening/night. No frills, no thrills. Nice bartenders. Cute napkins! Glad it's still around, since SF is constantly changing and our classic places are dying right and left.
author: Theresa C.

description: One of the worst experiences. The female bartender was very rude to us and to others. She was offended when a couple came in and asked for the other bartender.
author: Daniel M.

description:
Perhaps one of my favorite bars in the city. It is never over crowded and the cocktails are top notch. If you ever want a real cocktail, not some watered down mixed drink, this is the place for you! 

There are a few table in the front, bar seating, and small tables in the back. Every time I have been here, I have been able to get a table for two. The noise level is really good to have a conversation in. It is never too loud or too annoying. It is a cash only place, so be prepared.
author: Mariana V.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE! There's almost always a dog here. The owners are awesome, they make good drinks. The environment is great. DRINKS ARE CHEAP!!! (For San Francisco) 

There's one male bartender who is intense and weirdly aggressive but other than that this place is our favorite in town.
author: Brandi P.

description:
For an SF native, Zam Zam is a mainstay.
If you aren't from the City, more likely you saw its small take in Anthony Bourdain's show.

While his take was a somewhat stuffy bar where they don't accept any orders but martinis, this place is definitely not pretentious.   Bourdain was correct that they make amazing martinis (gin or vodka), but they have a bigger selection of cocktail drinks than implied.  No dumb mixers mind you, mainly old style cocktails.

The decor is something out of casablanca, having a Mediterranean/Middle Eastern influence.  Above all though, they do serve bottled beers and simple drinks like whiskey and coke.  But if you come to this bar, you have to buy a martini.  Why you may ask? Because it's that F!@#$!#@$! great!  

More importantly, the bartenders aren't as stuck up as Bourdain made it seem (neither are the denizens of SF, but a point of another time).  They easily welcomed our whole group although this was rather large.  We were especially obnoxious for coming right at last call, but he made a delicious stiff drink regardless.  

Come for the martinis and great vibes!
author: Joel Christian A.

description:
Aub Zam Zam is one of the Bucket List Bars to visit in San Francisco.  It's reputation is well-deserved.  I have spent more than a few hours in bars across the country and I can think of no place that is like this place.  And, I have to laugh at some of the reviews that you'll find on Yelp.  Oh, 1 Star folks...  You simply don't know your history.  

Oh, how rich is the history.  Zam Zam is a beautiful bar in the Haight which is first and foremost defined by its stunning Middle Eastern decor.  The centerpiece is the horseshoe shaped bar that surrounds a gorgeous mural.  As you walk in you are quickly transported off of Haight Street into a world that could come out of the movies.  The lighting is dark and there are many spots to grab a seat and a quiet conversation.  No TV's.  No pretension.  Just a classic bar with classic drinks.  Cash only.  

To hear Yelp reviewers gripe about service ignores any sense of the man who built this bar.  Bruno Mooshei was a man who had his standards and expected people to meet them in his establishment.  Read through some of the articles from when he passed - this man was an institution because he had his vision.  He wasn't afraid to tell people to leave if they were not part of that vision.  As Omar once said in The Wire:  "A Man has to have a Code".  It isn't exactly quite that way anymore, but there is still an edge.  This is a drinkers bar.  This is a place for people who have authenticity.  

The poison of choice here is the Gin Martini.  This bar was once called by Herb Caen the "Holy Shrine of the Dry Martini".  Ice cold.  Straight up.  They have a full bar and I have found the bartenders to be pretty darn cool.  Sitting at the horseshoe bar, looking at the mural and drinking a gin martini makes a man feel pretty damn smart for a few minutes.  It brings you back to a simpler time.  Don't miss this experience.
author: Adam S.

description:
This bar is the best. I came here and brought my friends visiting from Australia. We were looking for a place to just have drinks and hangout after dinner. I've been here once before but quickly, for a shot. 
I usually order vodka sodas but I noticed everyone was drinking martinis so I decided what the heck, may as well try something different. I also noticed an article on the wall that Zam Zam had been making martinis since the 40's so I figured they're must be doing something right. Also, the bar isn't pretentious like a lot of them in SF can be. 
The martinis's were amazing, so delicious and very strong. The bartender , he was very nice as well as the security. The patrons there friendly too. We ended up staying there until last call. We left Zam Zam making new friends . I'll go there every time I'm in SF.
author: Nadia G.

description:
It's unfortunate that this has to be my first review on here but I've had it with this place. I should preface by saying that I live 2 blocks from Zam Zam and have visited this bar about 15 times in the last 3 years. This is NOT the first time I've had a bad experience with the bartender in this situation, but tonight was the worst.   
    I went into Zam Zam tonight and had a pretty pleasant time talking with some of the bar regulars and after having had 1 beer realized I needed to get some more cash out so I go to the ATM get 80$ out and order another drink. I should first mention that during the time it took for me to drink one beer(30mins) the bartender had 2 shots with a regular sitting next to me. That being said I get my change back and I got 1$. I got the bartenders attention and let her know her know I gave her a 20$ and that my change was incorrect ...no harm done yet if I could get the correct change. She snapped at me saying "you gave me a 10$" yet she still angrily gave me the correct change after hesitating for a couple minutes...all while continuing to repeat that I was wrong. 
     She then continued to give me attitude and wouldn't speak to me as I tried asking her over to speak to her about the situation in hopes to clear the air. I didn't touch my drink or the change and when I finally got her to talk to me I asked (having been in there many times before and served by her on a few occasions) "Why would I go get money out just to try to scam you for a few dollars? You've seen me in here at least a few times before." Her response being "At this point I don't really give an F*** what you're trying to do. I've had a long weekend and I just wanna get the hell out of here so there's nothing to talk about. Take the damn money. I don't wanna talk about it."

Now the last thing I want to do is try to wind down with a drink while sitting at a bar in which the inebriated bartender is convinced you're trying to steal from them. So instead of any form of an apology from her she just says in a threatening way"all I know is at the end of the night ..if my drawer is off then I'll know it was you." 

So I left the untouched drink and ALL of the leftover change and I let her know why I was leaving. Enjoy the extra 20$

Look, we all have bad days but if you're willingly gonna work in the service industry then at least do a better job at not taking it out on your customers. I'd giver her the benefit of the doubt but after talking to my bartender roommates and finding out they have had similar experiences with her, and judging by the multiple bad reviews regarding her attitude, this isn't the first time. 

I wont be returning ...at least while she's at the bar. Such a bummer because I always liked how laid back that spot was.
author: Max S.

description: Really cool bar, open late, with chilled relaxed staffers serving drinks making sure everyone is having a good time and nicely lubricated. Feels real low key and intimate yet perfectly busy at the same time. Loved it.
author: Steven V.

description: This is where u go to make the magic happen on the Haight. I mean its pretty popular... Its  Been on Bourdains map. But if u get a chance to bring your date here. U got a real shot.  They tend to make strong drinks here and the ambiance is great. Worth checking out if its not busy in there.
author: Ryan N.

description: Friendly. Relaxed. Reasonable prices. I love this place. Whenever I return to this part of town I will definitely stop in. A gem of a place. If you are lucky, Kundan will be bartending. She is super nice, helpful and knows her booze!
author: Alice J.

description: I walked into Sinatra's "Summer Wind".   And things got better from there.  Cash only.  Know what you are getting into, have fun.
author: Jeff J.

description:
Wow dude, you don't shake a gin martini
You don't shake a gin martini You don't shake a gin martini You don't shake a gin martini You don't shake a gin martini You don't shake a gin martini You don't shake a gin martini You don't shake a gin martini You don't shake a gin martini You don't shake a gin martini You don't shake a gin martini You don't shake a gin martini.
author: Akash K.

description: OK so how many times have I been here and never went to Zam Zam? I don't know but this time it was my first stop in town, that might not have been the best idea after flying all day and not eating, but hey let the vaca begin! A little back story on the place, it's been around since 1941 and the owner/bartender was quite a character, only women got napkins for their drink, you sat at the bar NOT at the table, only gin was used (lots of it, still do) and there was a 2 drink limit, wise man may he RIP. You only need 1, really you do, I went for 2 hence the not quite my best idea, but I made it. The decor is all old Persia, very lovely really. Drinks are strong, really really strong. Very cool this place is still here, there is a lot of history in this place you must go.
author: Karen R.

description:
There's not many seats so get in where you fit in. Im pretty sure it's cash only.  The bartender with all the tatts is everything but he's not a fan of mixed drinks. My kinda guy! 

Drinks are stiff and reasonable and the battens keeps it real.  There's some interesting people in this watering hole but this review is only for a Thursday night so who knows.
author: Niah N.

description:
While Alembic is my go to bar in Haight-Ashbury, Zam Zam is my go to bar before Alembic opens.

Zam Zam feels more like something out of an Indiana Jones movie than it does a dive bar on Haight, especially if you sit in the back area. The main area has a horseshoe shaped bar, with a fantastic mural behind it. The bar offers a few beers in bottle, and mostly liquor. 

While I've only been a few times, the crowd has always been lively and friendly, easy to start up conversations with those around you, or keep to yourself. The staff is likewise friendly and sociable with the regulars.

So if looking for a quick, solid drink, I highly recommend Zam Zam. And now we must plot to recapture the Golden Paw...
author: Michael C.

description:
Seriously enjoyed this bar. Just kind of stumbled upon it during happy hour. 

Ordered:
Beer - opened with finesse
Tom Collins - gin tastic
Martini(s) - perfection, poured right to the rim

First 5 - 10 min eyed down by locals. 
After 10 min made friends with everyone at the bar! Shared IG's and snaps. Had amazing conversations. 

The bar is magical.
author: Amanda T.

description:
Not a Safe Place for the Lesbian Community - Avoid this Bar!

A few weeks ago, I was in Zam Zam. It was late on a Thursday night. I was with a woman. I am also a woman. Let's be real, two lesbians in a San Francisco bar isn't particularly notable. The woman and I had a few drinks. We began kissing. Sure, it was a kiss: an act of intimacy between two strong women. It was not excessive, disgusting or aggressive. I noticed the bartender walk towards the back of the bar.  

He stopped, looked at us, and he said: 

"Excuse me, this is a family bar." 

I began to laugh, thinking perhaps the bartender was joking with us. He clarified and confirmed that he was in fact, not joking. After sitting on it for a few weeks, I felt I wanted to write this review. It wasn't necessarily the fact that he made us feel unwelcome. It was the label that we were in fact, "not family." That family values somehow became relevant on Haight street on a weeknight. I don't recommend any LGBTQ person go to this bar, especially two women. You are not welcome nor regarded as family.
author: Claire S.

description:
Cheapest and strongest drinks you'll ever have in you're life. The first sip of my cocktail I inhaled because my body thought it was just alcoholic fumes. 

Lam bam slam kabam

AAA+++ would zam again.

I even bought a shirt.
author: Siamak S.

description: Cool artwork and friendly ambiance, great drinks... though I hear you may not want to use the restroom during your visit.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Stay away from this terrible and scary environment! Worst bartenders, employees, and customer crowd in the whole neighborhood! If I could give them 0 stars I would. One off duty bartender locked her dog in a tiny closet for so long it started barking and disrupting the peace so we said something. After spending over $100 on cocktails we thought it was appropriate to request that the dog stop barking. Not to mention how inhumane it is to leave your dog locked in a closet! Both the bartender who was working at the time and the off duty bartender/dog owner started yelling at us and defending the dogs bark, so we left.
     We quickly realized the off duty bartender was waiting for us outside and began antagonizing us and instantly head butted my husband. What a psycho! If Yelp allowed profanity I'd be using it here to describe her and her cheap, violent, scary behavior. She sucks at head butting and missed his nose but split his lip open. No one at Zam Zam's helped break up the crazy woman attacking my husband - a very scary visual. Finally a Hobson's Choice bouncer interfered and stopped her violence - thank you!
    We frequent the neighborhood often but it's safe to say we will never return to Zam Zam's again, unless it's with the Cops and the Humane Society. Their martinis aren't even good anyway. I suggest spending your money at Hobson's Choice down the block for their quality people, drinks, and atmosphere.
author: sarah b.

description:
Okay first of all, I love this place. It's dark, quiet and there are no TV's. My favorite bartender of all time Kundan tends bar here. I met her here. For the first six months of coming to this bar after work I would ignore the bar patrons, pay for my drinks and tip well and I was never bothered while I played Words With Friends and that was all super great after a long day of work. I ended up finally establishing a relationship with other regulars and the amazing Kundan as well who clued me into the fact that I'd get more bang for my buck if I ordered a Titos Martini instead of a Titos Greyhound which is my go-to drink. It's definitely a martini place. You walk in and the entire bar is people drinking her delicious martinis. 
One day my phone battery died and I was forced to actually talk to people and it turned out great. I met a very dear friend here. 

So why not 5 stars? 

There is a bartender named Genevieve who loves to talk shit. About what? About who? I don't know. Her employers? A bar patron shushed her while she was on a rampage about how much she hated working here. She dropped names, but she glanced looked over at me diligently focused on my Words With Friends game and proclaimed "She's nobody. She doesn't know." 
On another occasion she literally screamed and cursed out a customer and refused to make any drinks that involve a shaker and poured her a glass of wine with a straw in it. What the heck? She's also denied me service for Playing Words with Friends on my phone while sitting at the bar, and then commenced to speak loud enough so I could hear that she enforces no cell phones in the bar. She feels comfortable speaking down to paying customers and I have decided I will not be coming into Zam Zams's while she's tending bar. 

She's a cancer.
author: Vanessa B.

description:
I wished I can give this place no stars...

So it was a Saturday, my friends and I came into this bar to get a drink for my friend's birthday. When we first entered, there was barely anyone there (maybe 5 other people including the bartender). The room was dim and it was quiet. The bartender immediately asked us to show all of our ID's. My friend, Kathy and I needed to use the restroom, so we left our ID's at the bar while the bartender checked and went for the restroom.

We were actually using the restroom, not just to mess around or do anything stupid. However, I do admit we were just cracking jokes while waiting on each other (It was a one stall bathroom). Out of no where, the bartender barges into the restroom and just stares at us (at this point, Kathy and I were both done using the toilet and were just cleaning up), and we felt so uneasy by the way she just stood there and stared at us so I asked her "do you need to use the restroom.....) and she said "no" and so Kathy and I were like.. umm okay?... strange.. anyways, she left the restroom without saying anything else.

Kathy and I were still in the restroom for another minute or so cleaning up and laughing (we laugh a lot with each other - and no we were not under the influence). Then the bartender once again comes into the restroom and said "The restroom is for customers only, and your friends outside told me you two weren't going to order anything, so..." and Kathy and i were just thinking wtf..???? who the hell is this lady. By the way, Kathy was going to order a drink, and she told the bartender that. The bartender then says "well you're friends didn't have cash (it's a cash only bar btw) so they all left"... Kathy and I were still so shocked by this woman's attitude. We then said we are done using the restroom and then she left. We followed her back to the bar to see that our friends were all gone, so we were about to just walk out too and she said "You want your ID back?" (attitude tone of voice) and I said "yeah" so she gave it to me.

When we got outside, we saw our friends and they said they didn't have cash so they want to go to the ATM to get cash and come back. Kathy and I did not want to come back in there after what we just encountered, we told them what had just happened to us. My other friend Jen told us that when we were in the restroom, she was trying to take a picture of the bar area and the bartender told her that she can't take pictures at the bar, and so Jen told her that she technically wasn't sitting at the bar, and the bartender said "you have a point".. and then when Jen and my other friends said they didn't have cash and had to leave to get cash, the bartender said "Is this because I told you you couldn't take a picture". It was stupid... Needless to say, we didn't come back.

The way that bartender treated Kathy and I was especially rude. I can't believe how rude she was. Seriously, there was no line for the restroom, and we were serious about sitting down and buying drinks. But she definitely changed our minds about being there. I would not recommend this place! Instead, we ended up going to a place called The Milk Bar. Our bartender there was very chill and cool and took a shot with us. Don't go to Zam Zam seriously.
author: Katelin N.

description: We walked in at 1am and the bartender yelled at us that they were closed. They were clearly open and discriminating against us. They lost 3 customers in the process.
author: Brown B.

description:
My friends and I went here last night. We had four rounds of drinks over the course of a couple hours.  Eventually, we ended up heading over near the front door while deciding whether to stay for another round of head elsewhere.  The bouncer approached us and asked us why we weren't drinking. We explained we had been here for a couple hours and had definitely been drinking. He said that he didn't give a fuck and that if we weren't drinking we needed to leave.  That was one of the rudest encounters I've ever experienced at a bar and will definitely not be back. There are plenty of bars in the city and I recommend going to one of those over Zam Zam.

 To top it all of I was not drinking since I was the designated driver and most reasonable people would understand this. Either the bouncer does not know what the definition of designated driver is or does not value the safety of the patrons.
author: Dan C.

description: My first legal drink was here and I wouldn't have it any other way!! It was delicious and I like the intimate setting :)
author: Robyn H.

description:
Me and my friends were having a great time last weekend when we decided to go here, not a long line to the bar and it was pretty fun. Then we made the mistake of being seen by the bouncer without drinks in our hands. "I don't care how many drinks you've had, order something or get the f*** out!" 
That guy could definitely use some therapy, because he really put a bad spin on that part of our night.
If they're trying to force all their patrons into binge drinking just to make money, they could easily just charge more to make their money instead of potentially putting people in dangerous situations by encouraging their employees to force patrons to drink constantly or get out. Clearly we are not the only ones who had a similar experience.
author: Spencer C.

description: Hit or miss. First time I was there I had a good experience; the gentleman working the bar seeming to know his craft. On my second visit, there was a surley woman working the bar who claimed to be an expert but it became quickly apparent she had no clue on how to make a proper cocktail. Honestly, who shakes a Manhattan?
author: Ronald F.

description: Compared to others reviews I feel we might have been at different bar.  Maybe like "night & day?" And we were there late afternoon.  The barmaid was friendly, efficient, and personable, and in no way pushy to have more drinks.  There was no bouncer.  The few other patrons were friendly. The decor is: other...like wow, kinda out there but very cool nonetheless.  I wouldn't go 30 miles out of my way to go here, but it was very pleasant place to hang out for a bit.
author: LeAnne L.

description: Such a fun little place to visit. I had a martini that was made exactly how I like it. I especially love the secluded seating away from the bar if you want to chat
author: Jeanette b.

description:
Zam Zam is a locals' favorite cash only bar, that isn't going to convince you that it's the best at something. 

The place is small, but I've never felt it to be crowded - quiet enough for a conversation. Walls have some nice decor, especially the mural behind the bar.

Sometimes a no-frills bar is exactly what you need.
author: Artem A.

description: Would NOT go back again.  A friend and I went in to take a quick shot before continuing our shopping... the bartender had an attitude, I felt like I was interrupting her conversation and bothering her by waiting to order and I ordered 2 double shots but was given 2 singles and charged for doubles.
author: Paola I.

description:
A group of us girls stopped here to use the bathroom and ended up staying to have a few drinks.

This is an awesome bar. The atmosphere is laid back  in fact, I didn't care if my girls and I stayed there all day while visiting SF. The music was awesome, straight from a sweet jukebox and the bartender was entertaining. Cool little piece of history too. Opened in 1948 with the same layout still existing. 

Best Bloody Mary!! Strong, spicy and full of flavor.
author: Sylvia J.

description:
The two stars are for the strength of the drinks and the prices ($6 each for a vodka/cranberry and vodka/soda).

I had a major gripe at this place. I was visiting San Francisco from Los Angeles and my sister & I decided to stop at this bar after we had walked around the neighborhood. The bartender was a young woman who's maybe in her late 20s or early 30s w/ short black hair. She was working on a Saturday afternoon.

While my sister and I sipped our drinks, the bartender was talking loudly with two men sitting at the bar. It was hard to ignore them because their voices were at a decent volume. No big deal, obviously...

...until we heard them talking shit about Los Angeles. Now listen, I don't give a flying fuck if someone doesn't love my city. It ain't for everyone, and I would prefer most snooty transplants go back to whatever shitty town they came from and leave us natives alone. However, the bartender decided to partake in the shit talking and that is beyond rude and ignorant. You're an employee at an establishment that probably sees more tourists than locals, so disrespecting people from other cities is in poor taste. I don't give a shit if it's a dive bar. Act like you've been somewhere.

This wasn't just about the criticism of my city - I hit my limit when they all started talking shit about the people. Yes, the people from LA, aka my sister and me. I went up to the bar for more drinks and spoke up, because I felt like putting these idiots in their places. One guy, clearly the drunkest, sounded downright idiotic with his "LA ISNT A CITY THOUGH CUZ LIKE U GOTA DRIVE EVERYWHERE" and the bartender, trying desperately to backtrack on all the shit I heard her talk, explained that she lived in LA for a "little bit" when she was in the entertainment biz, so those are the only types of people she hung around.

Anyway, I'm going off on a tangent here. It just left a bad taste in my mouth. San Francisco's a beautiful city, but transplants like that bartender (because, of course, she wasn't from either LA or San Francisco and neither were the two bozos talking to her) need to be mindful of the shit that comes out of her mouth when in the presence of mixed company.
author: Norma M.

description: I had the good luck to visit the Zam Zam several years ago for the first time. My father, uncle, and aunt spoke about their stops there before and after 49er games when they played at Kezar Stadium. That group has moved on the other side now. I mentioned to the bartender of my family history there and he bought me my first beer and we toasted them. Classy move by the bartender! Been back several times when I land out in the Haight.
author: Andy L.

description: I really liked to be here when I have nothing to do at home. Sometimes I bring my friends with me here and they loved it.  One of my favorite place to hangout.
author: Surya R.

description:
San Francisco is not the friendliest place I've ever been and lived. People can be a bit standoffish, too cool for school, or glued to their devices. So it was refreshing to sit down at the bar of Zam Zam with a girlfriend and immediately strike up conversation with our neighbors. The guy on my left lives in Portland now and was visiting his adult daughter. The guy on my friend's right was waiting for his girlfriend to finish shopping next door. They were chatty but not overly so.

The bartender looked like one of the Bowery Boys, like he could work at a shipyard in Philadelphia -- Popeye muscles, tattoos and hat pushed down low. He was no nonsense and made a good Manhattan. The atmosphere is dark, there are a lot of nooks and crannies to get in lost in and have a private conversation but the ten or so seats around the bar are the prize. Lights glittering off silhouettes of bottles and a large Persian (?) mural above it, this is a dive bar with a little charm.
author: Angelique L.

description:
This is one of the first bars that I have been to before even I lived in San Francisco. We stumbled upon it when we were tired of shopping and needed a cold beer. We sat next to some old regulars and took Jameson shots! Might be one of the reasons that I have been living in San Francisco for the past four years. 
It's on Haight Street. It's really small & intimate. It has such a great atmosphere. If you are into low key and original little hole in the walls, you will love this space!
author: Tumay A.

description: Bartenders are rude. The bar markets itself as a 'cocktail place' yet there is no cocktail menu, bartenders only know basic, well-known drinks. My boyfriend was not feeling well that day (he wasn't drunk), yet a bartender passed by and said 'no sleeping at the bar' - my boyfriend raised his head up. Then a different guy who works there passed by and said 'this guy has to go'. On the way out I told him 'you just made sure we never come back to this bar'. He said 'good'. I said 'do you seriously think we are some kind of drunks?', and he said 'yes'. Excuse me, but even if you thought my boyfriend was drunk... YOU SERVE ALCOHOL! YOU SHOULDN'T BE PENALIZING PEOPLE FOR DRINKING! But HE WASN'T EVEN DRUNK, and didn't throw up, cause any mess or trouble. He just sat with his head down. Are they seriously so authoritarian and make the worst assumptions about people who don't follow some arbitrary strict social norms they like? Not worth going there at all.
author: Alexandra S.

description: This seems like a fun bar, but the bouncer was extremely rude to my friends and me. I showed up at Zam Zam tonight and my friends and I easily had 3 drinks each over the course of a couple hours. After a while my friend and I were standing by the door planning our next move and the bouncer (I think his name was Jeff - he had a black and gray beard) told us "this is a drinking bar" and that we "needed to order a drink or leave". I told him that we were planning our next move and that we had each ordered 3 drinks already. Jeff told us "I don't give a fuck how many drinks you've had - you need to order a drink or get out". I've honestly never been told this in any bar I've been to. My friends and I were very offended and needless to say I won't be back to Zam Zam.
author: Paul K.

description: Good drinks and great vibes. The decor is distinct and definitely gives this small bar a lot of personality.
author: Natalie M.

description: I stopped by on a whim while walking The Haight. There isn't a menu, which I love. I just told the bartender the types of drinks I normally have and she made me a 'Perfect Manhattan'. It was delicious. I enjoyed the dark, hole-in-the-wall feel of this place and will be back the next time I am in the area.
author: Samantha W.

description: This is a fun little bar. You have to order at the bar and bring your drink back to your table. It's also cash only, but there is an ATM inside. There's a cool murel on the wall above the bar that makes for interesting visual excitement. Try it out on your next stroll down Haight for a fun pit stop.
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
Aub Zam Zam
SF: Haight-Ashbury
Saturday March 3, 2012
Four Stars

[SF#6]

Dive-y, Hole-in-the-wall cash bars are always filled with good people and great bartenders. Aub Zam Zam was no exception.  We ordered a total of 9 dry Plymouth Gin Martinis which cost $76.  The Bartendress was friendly and could make a proper martini (stirred and not shaken)*.   Her dog was so cute with its over-sized paws.  Cave Canem! b/c that doggie bites.

*I swear the next I am asked to make a shaken martini, I am going to pour the liquor, ice, and vermouth into my mouth, gargled it and spit into a chilled cocktail glass.
author: Leonard L.

description:
Cross this place off your list. We went in for a casual drink, I ordered a pomegranate martini and the bar tender snapped at me saying he didn't have the ingredients and then made our whole group show our IDs again. 

We then ordered three rum and cokes. The bartender brought back a gin and tonic, and two whiskey sprites and refused to take our drinks back. 

The service was awful. The sitting area is too small. If you're not a regular in this place don't expect to be welcomed in.
author: Lee S.

description: Lovely place... Chill atmosphere... also loved that I was able to bring my dog.  Drinks were decent-- another plus, of course!  Definitely want to stop by again sometime.
author: Janette M.

description:
The aura in this bar is very nice, very Arabesque. But the bartender was wicked cold, and I absolutely felt the racist eyes from the older patrons on my cousin and I. 

But overall good happy hour specials definitely
author: Kenneth S.

description:
So glad we happened to peep into this little bar on our walk down Haight St. while visiting SF. Such a chill spot. I can't remember the last time I sat at a bar...but it's such a tiny space that the bar is pretty much where it's at and because it is so intimate you can easily meet new people who are sitting next to you or chat up the bartender. 

The bar has awesome Indian (?) decor and has the original design from the 40s. They even have a photo from New Years 1948 (I think) on the wall. Looks exactly the same today! 

Space reminded me kinda of the coffee shops in Amsterdam...minus the "coffee". LOL.

Great drinks and bartender was on it! We had Irish coffees. They will make pretty much anything. Cash only. Great music coming from a juke box...I guess that means it's also a good crowd!
author: Lina K.

description: Food is amazing.  However order 30min in advance chances are it will still not b ready once u get there.  We went on a weekday at a time where the restaurant was empty.  He took 45 mins to cook 3burgers.
author: Sean J.

description:
Let me say I'm giving this Place 4 stars but in all honesty I doubt many people would give it that nearly 3. There's always some serious regulars here who r friends with the crazy drunk Eastern European bartender swapping shrunken stories or yelling about something or other. The place is run down and has some serious history. The photos on the wall from the 20s really speak about its origins. That said this is not a classy bar and I'd never get nething more fancy than a whiskey ginger here. The bartenders don't know how to make a cocktail for shit. I've had some of the worst drinks into life here. I stick to the tall cans of PBR for $2.50 cuz it gets u drunk and if u get enough I the by can make pyramids on the tables in the back.

I come here for a few reaSons and a few reasons only. Cheap PBR that gets u good and drunk, the free jukebox full of awesome jazz and classic tunes and the low lighting candles that light up the tables which make for good conversation with ur friends. Red walls and middle eastern style also make this a welcome hangs of pace from the other bars on haight. I'd recommend this as a good first stop any nite cuz it's never crowded and never changing right down the tapes up padding on the walls!
author: Harrison M.

description: My favorite bar in the City! Persian murals, dark lighting, charm and elegance with amazing martinis. Best jukebox with jazz and classic standards. Feels like stepping back in time. I ponder the many guests here before me over the years. If the walls could talk...
author: Anastasia A.

description:
I was told I was at Zam Zam's my first night in San Francisco. I guess I was?

I arrived at my drinking buddy's house in the Haight around 9pm. He promptly made me a cocktail. Then another cocktail. Then another. He claims I asked for them in quick succession. I think he was trying to kill me... and he almost succeeded.

One of the last things I remember clearly is putting on make-up and my pal being all "why are you doing that?" and I was like "I just figured we were going out". And then he laughed to himself about how he was about to take me to Zam Zam's. 

They make good Manhattans and they have cheap PBR.

PEPPER POINTS: For the rad jukebox. 

PEPPER'S PISSED: At Vivek S for giving me alcohol poisoning.
author: Evelyn A.

description: How in the hell does this dump have 4 stars? Bartender think he's such a tough guy with his fake prison tattoos and barking at customers who make the mistake of stumbling into this place. I have no idea what this bar is trying to be. Are we in Morocco or some shitty biker bar outside of Fresno? It's also very dusty and dirty inside - fixing that would be a good start.
author: Brandon H.

description:
Small town, local vibe. Decently priced drinks, but like most other places in the city it was cash only which I really don't like. I didn't want to borrow from my friends so I just cut myself off.

I would go back if someone recommended because the bartender was really cool and she had her dog in the place, but it wouldn't be my top choice.
author: Jennifer S. C.

description: This Small local bar in the Haight is fantastic. Chris the bartender was amazing. Awesome to sit at the bar and watch him make great drinks for his patrons. I strongly recommend to make this a stop on your visit to San Francisco.
author: Willito G.

description:
I love this bar so much I want to BE this bar.   I even found the PERFECT pair of heart shaped sunglasses here that someone left on a table, it was destiny man and they were meant to be mine so I took them.  I wear them every day.  If you guys ever need a bartender, HIRE ME!  I'm not an alcoholic, I have a French style mean streak and still have been called charming a few times, and I'd never even be a bartender unless it was here.  I make a mean Old Fashioned, and perfect Manhattans.  Like Blondie once sang to the President of the USA, "Call Me!"

All you people, read all the Yelp reviews of this place, such good information and history that I can't begin to top.  I read 50+ reviews like I was reading a best selling novel.  It's been around since the beginning of time, or so I've read.  That's because this place is too legit to quit.
author: Super L.

description:
Had another fantastic evening at Aub Zam Zam last night. The place was full of good people, the jukebox was jumpin', and as usual, the cocktails were magnificent.

What was really great, I must say, is that there wasn't one PBR-worshipping mouth-breather to be found. All of the revelers were people who looked like they can write, spell, order a proper drink and not miss the point of why this bar is great.

Like the internet itself, Yelp allows willful ignorance to be loudly worn like a dubious badge of honor. Dim-bulb reviewers jump at the chance to exclaim: "Look at me! I have an opinion and an internet connection, and I'm very limited in my view of the world" Don't you want to know more?" I have some mean things to say so I'm going to write them down. That way, I'll feel better about myself and you'll think I'm informed and edgy."

Um, no. Go back to hipster land. I'm sure they hang on every word.

When I go Zam Zam, I order a Booker's Manhattan, stirred gently, served up. I've been bar tending for years (and used to get paid to do it), and I've never had a Manhattan made so flawlessly as at Zam Zam. All of the bartenders make them very well, but Andrea makes them the best. She is not only a delightful person, but she is also a very skilled bartender. She is Czech. She has a lovely accent. And she never drinks while she tends bar. These are facts. End of story.

So keep raising that right hand, keep shouting, and keep walking.
author: Jeffrey B.

description:
This is hands down the most divey dive bar I've ever been to. The crowd and the interior are both super busted and super random. This is where you go when you've just been dumped, you're wearing sweatpants, and you haven't showered in 3 days.*

*Thats not why I was there.
author: Emily D.

description:
A semicircle bar, dimly lit with red light; some kind of kama sutra pastoral scene on the wall; and a salty barmaid who opens pbr's with a knife. 

Yup. Win. 

Is it a dive? I dunno. I like it, whatever it is.
author: Rob R.

description: We stumbled in randomly and had no idea that a wonderful martini bar experience  were in for. We met some great locals that gave us all sorts of recommendations. Everyone there was a regular apparently but super welcoming. It's a must visit for expertly made drinks at reasonable cost.
author: James And Gina S.

description:
Love this bar. Right out of the forties. Fantastic jukebox..endless
great selections. I drop in when I'm in the area for a martini. It
gets busier later. Cash only. Neighborhood people come here.
You can avoid the college crowd that's littered down the street.
Bartenders pour a nice stiff one and you can chat up with some
cool people, or just shut up and groove to the tunes. Dark and
bewitching atmosphere. My kinda place
author: Michelle L.

description:
The REAL DEAL for dive bar fans ... it doesn't get much more divey than this. The atmosphere was probably exactly the same in the 1950s and 1960s ... it looks like nothing was updated or cleaned since then. A total blast from the past ...

Located in Haight Ashbury district of San Francisco the Zam Zam room is one of the oldest bars in the area. A watering hole to the many hippies and counter culture icons of the 1960s, it isn't hard to imagine this place filled with Beatnicks and Hippies.

The bar is super dark in a closet-like way and almost uncomfortable feeling. The barstaff puts you at ease though. The afternoon guy (bar opens at 3 p.m.) was a trip. Very nice and polite and you could tell he loved the bar he worked at.

The drink prices are decent here ... they have a very hard to use jukebox (both hard to use and jukebox being important things in dive bar culture) and the overall atmosphere is laid back when its not crowded.

It used to be that the Martini was the go-to drink here, expertly crafted and served the way the crusty old bartender wanted to serve it. Bourdaine went here while in San Francisco on The Layover and had some interesting stories to tell.

This is a fun place ... I wish I had time to stop by at night because I am sure there are some interesting characters who frequent this place as regulars. Next time I am in Haight Ashbury, I will certainly stop by.

This is a dive bar classic that can't be missed if you are stopping into Haight Ashbury.
author: E T.

description: Kundun is an amazing mixologist. Made very creative and fun drinks that don't even have names!
author: JW Z.

description: Happy 75th Anniversary Aub Zam Zam!  Happened to stop by for a drink and enjoyed excellent cocktails and company.   Highly recommended for a well made drink and conviviality.  Please... 75 more years!!!
author: M C.

description:
I can understand the negative reviews about this place... but can't say I agree. Stopped by on a Thursday night during a date and when we first got there, both the crowd and bartender seemed cold and disinterested in welcoming new comers. However, I'm pretty sure that's how a lot of small bars are that have their regulars--and like most places in SF, showing kindness to others resulted in equal kindness back.

After getting comfortable at the bar and talking to the people around us, we immediately felt like we belonged. Like a lot of bars on Haight, it's dim inside and the place has a pretty vintage, almost speak-easy feel to it (plus one for flattering lighting on a date!). The martinis were flowing and the juke box was full of golden oldies and soulful selections. This is not a superficial place and if I lived closer, I would easily become a regular.
author: Sam D.

description:
Love this place. Super genuine and unique. 

There are definitely a lot of regulars but they don't make you feel out of place. 
We stopped in late on a Monday night and it wasn't crowded but entertaining. 
The drinks are strong and traditional. The bartender wasn't over the top friendly but she knew what she was doing and she was very attentive. 
My favorite thing about this place is the aesthetics.. The scene behind the bar is so interesting! 

Cool place to take the hard to impress out of town friend.
author: Sydney S.

description: My little neighborhood spot :) The ambiance is excellent - you can feel the history just oozing out of the walls. Make sure you bring cash xo
author: Lauren P.

description:
Zam Zam has great lighting, cozy little tables, vintage-y Persian decor, and lovely cocktails. It's a pretty excellent spot for a date, albeit on the divey side. Caveat: try not to set your date to take place at a time that turns out to be 15 minutes after the Giants win the World Series - it totally kills the mood (this happened to me, improbably enough). 

Date night aside, it's also a pretty chill venue to just hang out as a neighborhood bar. I've never had a bad experience with a bartender, and baseball revelers notwithstanding the weeknight crowd tends to be pretty laid-back.  Of all the Haight Street bars, I gravitate most toward this one on a casual night.

In short - I recommend.
author: Janna M.

description: One of the most low key bars and the bartenders here are lovely and wonderful. During week days, small turnout, but if you're looking for somewhere to decmpreds, this is your spot.
author: Merisa R.

description: Super creepy, kind of dirty, constantly smells like weed.  Do NOT order the vodka martini... It is JUST a glass of pure, cheap vodka.  The gin and tonic was fine... But with so many other options for cocktails in the Haight, why go here?
author: Allison M.

description: Love this place. This is an Assyrian/Persian owed business . Very good drinks, authentic gold rush !!!
author: Azin G.

description:
Tobah. You should be ashamed of ur business by associating ur cocktails as holy water of zam zam. U give persians a bad name.

 ZERO STARS!
author: Farah J.

description:
What a cool and unsuspecting spot in the Haight!

Just moved into the area, went exploring and stopped in here for a drink with some friends. It was very dim in there, but it added a cool ambiance to the place. The bartender was SUPER nice, cracked some good jokes with us, and served up some good drinks.

Although the place isn't very big it's still really cozy, their chairs are quite comfy, and the place seems to have been open since the 1940's since they have some old photos up of the place and it looks just like it did then, now (just a bit older, lol). I like that historic feel. I did like that the women's room was clean and had fun pink and bright green painted walls!

I would definitely come back here again because of the excellent service, welcoming feel, and dim/chill atmosphere. Perfect for grabbing drinks with friends.

ps- cash only, but there is an ATM inside.
author: Akvile D.

description:
Not only is the Jukebox and Ambiance amazing here, the drinks are amazingly stiff. They make one of the best Sazeracs I've ever had and have pretty decent prices. 

The staff are amazingly nice. One girl, Melody, saved my stuff that I accidentally left there after one too many Sazeracs and was going to write me a letter to come pick it up.
author: Andrew K.

description:
This bar had a soft focus memory place in my mind. I went here, at age 29, in 1990. This weekend, I returned, at age 47. 

The distinctive owner, Bruno - now dead, still existed in the form of a patron parroting the owner's catchphrases "The tables are CLOSED". The interior, with all the Persian art and objects was mostly the same, if a bit more shabby. 

The hippie-ish bartender was pleasant and friendly. The martinis were . . . martinis. I was happy to return, but the magic of this place has mostly faded. It's just a neighborhood bar now.
author: Erika G.

description: Very cool establishment but HORRIBLE service!! We initially walked in and thought wow this is a cool place. However the bartender that was working today (female bartender, daytime on Valentine's Day) did not even acknowledge us with a hello. Every question I asked was a rude, short, one word answer which made us feel extremely uncomfortable. After getting my drink I went to the restroom while my boyfriend waited for his. I got back and he told me to drink my drink fast because the bartender is not nice and he didn't want to be here. She literally threw down his money at the bar while she was meanwhile engaged with someone else who just walked in with no thank you or anything. We probably would have stayed for a while but what's the point? To be treated like crap? I'm a bartender myself and I would never treat anyone like that. Take your bad day somewhere else. Your establishment is on a very busy street so you should expect people that aren't regulars, however you should treat everyone like a regular.
author: Christine K.

description:
Imagine walking into a bar with 20 people inside on a Friday night.  You wait at the bar for 10 minutes watching as the bartender (who was drunk?  Stoned?  Incredibly incompetent?  All three?) fills two glasses with ice, stares blankly at some rum, dumps ice out of glasses, stares blankly at vodka, and then puts ice in glasses.  In order to avoid making a drink for someone else, she eventually asks for your drink order, which is a raspberry lemon drop.  After staring at you blankly for 30 seconds she tells you she has a long list of things to do, and it will take her at least 10 minutes before she's able to make your drink.  

So you wait.  For ten more minutes.

She hasn't made a single drink in this time.  She rinses out some glasses.  Plays with the ice some more.  Wipes a wet rag over some empty tables.  But she hasn't made a single drink.  In twenty minutes.  And she never will, dude.  She never will make that drink.

If this sounds fun to you, then by all means come here.  But it wasn't my idea of a good time so I won't be back.  Which is a shame, because the bar itself is clean-ish and the ambiance is fine, but when the one bartender in the place is incapable of doing what she was hired to do, it kind of ruins it for the rest of us.
author: Leith M.

description: Echoing other reviews, the service at this bar is terrible. The bartender was offensively impatient when waiting for my group to show IDs. When I asked which beers they had, he snapped at me for not having looked at the beers before talking to him. Every encounter we had with him was off putting. Needless to say, I won't be back to zam zam.
author: Alec L.

description:
What happen to this place? Here are my concerns:
- 3 dogs in a bar barking and acting up while adults try to enjoy a great conversation not good and very rude to patrons...is it a bar or a dog park?
- sorry but bartender didn't suggest any type of recommendations since no Prosecco and no milk at bar...very slow service
- the booze punch drink the bartender created was mediocre...but appreciated the effort...expected higher level of drink from a Mixologist 
-  place needs a good scrubbing from the bar itself to properly instructing bartenders on how to clean glassware...dipping glasses in/out of the bristles doesn't mean clean 

Pros:
Nice bar stools
author: Carlos G.

description: Fantastic ambience, delightful company and solid drinks. The bartender was very kind to this out-of-towner!
author: Allison H.

description: I used to go there when his dad ran the place in the late 70's and 80's.  Was proudly kicked out when I asked for a vodka gimlet, with "As Time Goes by" on the juke.  Great place!
author: Tony B.

description: My favorite place in the area to stop for drinks! It's a beautiful looking bar and the drinks are strong but not so strong that they don't taste good :) everyone here is always so friendly that it has the feel of a small town bar despite being in SF.
author: Janelle L.

description:
I guess this place got even more rep from "No Reservations," but I do enjoy bartenders that know their drinks and understand what a respectable drink is.  My father has been a bartender since the 70s for the Four Seasons and he taught me everything I need to know.  

But my reason for the two stars is because of my experience last night.... Needless to say the bartender was DRUNK, SPITTING IN THE SINK, AND
author: Nino P.

description: Joseph is the shiz÷!! Realest bartender out there. Gangster status and i appreciate him for that!
author: Brandi L.

description:
Verrrrry dim. Nearly pitch black in the backroom, the better to drink furtively even while amongst your friends.

Just found out that zamzam means "sacred spring" in Arabic. Cool!
author: Vanessa H.

description: If you're looking for a REAL San Francisco bar...look no further.  We come to the city very often and when we do, we always make it a point to stop in and enjoy an afternoon cocktail.  The best Vodka Martini in town reisides im the Zam Zam!!! An absolute must stop!!!
author: Steve C.

description: this bar is rad, like 1940's Morocco. Dark and intimate. My Old Fashoned wasnt the greatest, but it was ok. I will totally go back next time im in SF.
author: VALERIE Z.

description:
More kind and knowledgeable than I am used to. The gentleman in the vest behind the bar knows his craft.

Others can describe and recommend this small unlikely treasure of a bar better than I can.

I don't like bars. I like this bar.

Recommended? = Yes. It's a true San Francisco experience.
author: Chris R.

description:
I have no idea if the fabled Bruno still works here or not... but if he doesn't, it makes sense that I wasn't even close to being blown away. If he does, I suppose I missed him, because Aub Zam Zam seemed awfully Aub-Bor-Ing to me.

It was just your standard bar as far as I'm concerned. I guess they had a cool backdrop behind the bar, but the two times I've visited, it was butts to nuts with a high tide of Marina chode wads doing Jager Blasters and acting like 18 year old college freshmen with their first taste of freedom. If this Bruno character is anything like I imagine him to be... he'd have kicked these idiots out before they could even order their drinks. 

Certainly not a bad spot, but I'd avoid at all costs on the weekends.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
Love stopping by Aub Zam Zam at the end of a night in the Haight. The people I find there are friendly and talkative. The drink are strong and the bartenders and fast. The only reason it's a 4-star review is that the decor need an update badly and the bathroom is usually deplorable.

Thank god the lights are low and I stand up to piss.
author: Pete F.

description:
First time I went? I was tripping. I couldn't stop looking at the mural behind the bar.

I drink there once a month and I always say that I should go back more. Always an interesting mix at the bar  with older hippies stinking like weed, hipsters with moustaches, two coked-up Cougars from Palo Alto, a trio of Marina douc-a-b@gs in suits slumming it, and a random, drunk tourist from Scandinavia leading a discussion on Keirkagaard. 

The Crackhead factor is low inside ZZ. The derelicts stay outside on Haight Street. Don't feed the panhandlers after Midnight.
author: Taylor C.

description: Went here a few months back and just got a chance to write a little something. My friends and I came in for the first time, greeted by a new bartender. He was a huge dick. He was extremely rude and unfriendly. He definitely lacked experience. I mean, come on.. how do you mess up on a drink when someone asks for it "neat"? He put ice in it! Is he dumb? To remedy the issue, he just took the ice out. Never going back.
author: Wendy C.

description: My favorite bar in the haight. My favorite bartenders in all of SF. Great drinks, feels good, awesome interesting people. A bartender that doesn't ignore you and really tries to make you the best drink they can. I don't need to say much more. I love this place.
author: Skye J.

description: Well, I heard some buzz about this place so decided to check it out. Let's just say I don't see what all the fuss is about. I started out being ignored by the bartender and there was some loud old leftover hippie in there from the 60's who thought he was a huge star for having lived in the district since the 60's. Yeah, OK pal, whatever. Anyway, maybe you have to be drunk to appreciate the ambiance but I wasn't going to stick around that long. As far as I'm concerned it's just some old dive bar.
author: Will J.

description: Seating is a bit limited. The bartender was ok. The beer was fine. Yes, it's old and probably nostalgic for folks who've lived in the neighborhood for 20 years ... So many other bars to swing by in the neighborhood...
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Zam Zam is hands down the most interesting bar I know of in the city. I'm not sure if it's built above a sacred relic of san francisco or the hell mouth, but every time I go in there the experience is "real" and unforgettable.  

The place is a bar. I would say the bar service is "adequate", and maybe even a little above average. You don't go here to get the best drink in the city. You are going for the people. And the people are not going to be what you expect.

No matter how people are shaped or look on the surface, this spot is a magnet for the interesting. Almost every time I've gone there I've met people that I've formed deep bonds with. It's a wonder I don't go there more often but I think the universe just calls me to be there when "it's time".

Interesting facts: Fun juke box. Circular bar (it's really interesting in the sense that everyone ends up "facing each other"). The shape of the bar alone is a "conversation catalyst".  There are some small tables around too. There is always someone standing because of the limited seating, but I find that if you are there a reasonable amount of time you'll be awarded with a perch.

I don't doubt that the bartenders need to deal with some interesting folks from time to time so I think it's a mistake to take anything personally that happens upon first walking in there.  I've never been treated rudely.

I dare you to go and not have a great time. But it's like fishing. Just go in and wait for it to happen. Don't be in a rush. Enjoy the company.
author: Greg C.

description:
Here it is people, just gonna throw it on out there....Im a nerd, and a bit of a tourist. 
Saw this on No Reservations and new I had to check it out. 
I was not disappointed, I have a thing for darkly lit bars. This place had cool atmosphere, you can tell it has been around for years. 
Bar tender was a cool guy and was excited when I ordered a Jack Daniels Up. I think the people before me had ordered a round of Mint Juleps. 
Allegedly, the owner had some attitude issues while he was alive. If you came in and ordered something he didn't approve of he would not serve you.
author: Noel J.

description: One of the worst bar experiences I have ever had.  The bartendress was STANK and rude.  She gave my group the eye roll.  She even churned her neck after the eye roll.  She took GREAT pleasure in telling me that the bar was cash only after the drinks were poured.  That would not have been an issue EXCEPT...my credit card, which I set on the bar upon placing my order, was in plain sight throughout her pouring, shaking, and mixing.  The drinks were not complicated, so they were as expected - delicious mixed drink cocktails.  The funk, however, was thick in Zam Zam and I dare say I won't be back.
author: Sandy R.

description:
Kitschy inside decor, bordering shabby. It's dark enough to hid most of it, but the upholstery falling apart in the back makes it look more like a dive then giving it character. 
Had a greyhound, but canned grapefruit never tastes the same. Cute place for an intimate night in the back or an interesting conversation at the bar.
author: Naomi K.

description:
If it's good enough for Tony Bourdain, I'm sure it's good enough for any other tourist in town, which might mean this place has lost it's magic. 

Regardless, the place is awesome. The jukebox is all jazz, 50's, and Tom Waits. It's maybe 40% upbeat, and 60% depressing music which in my opinion is actually kind of awesome for a bar. 

The tiny space has a great feel to it, and the cocktails are mixed extremely well. My sidecar tasted like a million dollars.
author: Julian V.

description:
This is an interesting, unpretentious little bar that seems out of place (in a good way) for Haight. 

The space is small, fairly crowded, and dark. The drinks are cheap. The mural behind the bar is pretty, and we got our drinks in record time, even though the bartender had a lot going on at once. The noise volume didn't get too high, even when the place was at full capacity. I would come again.
author: Sonia M.

description: Love zam zam's especially Joseph the bartender and the history of the bar!!! Don't as k Joseph "what should I get" and men.... Don't ask for a napkin for your drink
author: Jenny R.

description:
I give this place a four so people won't think its that great. Also I miss Bruno, the old owner guy who used to kick everyone out for the most bizarre infractions like ladies ordering a second drink, or if you didn't tip him the 50 cent piece he'd give you for change. Martinis were only $2.50 and he'd kick everyone out of the bar and close it if a customer demanded another drink.

Anyway, I still love this neighborhood place and go there whenever someone from out of town visits. The Art Deco bar is amazing although the tables area is getting worn down now that the new owners allow it to be open. I can still hear Bruno yelling, "the tables are closed", whenever an unfamiliar client would try to sit there. I guess he knew it was fragile.

Bruno did make the best martinis I've ever had. The new bar tenders are good but it'll never be the same. That's not all bad, either.
author: david b.

description:
Stopped by with a friend last night for a drink while we waited for our table at another place down the street.

Liked it a lot!! 

Great place to relax and have a drink in a mellow but authentically awesome setting... my drink was good, the bartender was super nice and appealing... and I didn't feel like I was surrounded by hipsters... good find at 11:30 pm on a Saturday...
author: Dana G.

description:
My crumogeny old friend Sked recommended this place way before it was featured on Bordain's Travel Channel show.  And yet, I haven't made it until about two years ago.

In my few times at the Aub Zam Zam, even after asking about happy hour specials, I didn't get yelled at.  Which came as a bit of a disappointment.

The Zam Zam is a bit of a legend, and a decent place to get Shnookered on a Tuesday afternoon.
author: Rocco B.

description: Aub Zam Zam was one of my favorite bars when I lived on Haight Street. I love the cozy atmosphere and the free chex mix. They always make delicious dirty martinis! However, the last time I was here made me want to never return. The bartender was a petite hipster looking girl who was probably 25 but her raspy smoker voice was more like 55. She took a sip out of my drink before handing it to me to ensure it tasted okay. I WANTED TO DIE. I am the biggest germaphobe ever and I thought this was extremely unprofessional. She then put a pig mask on and proceeded to flash her nipples to the men sitting at the bar. Eh, sounds about right for the Haight.
author: Crystal P.

description: Came here on a Haight bar crawl, but I probably wouldn't come back again. They have cheap drinks, and the bartender was nice, but it had a weird smell and they have nothing on tap. The crowd is kind of strange. It was a weird mix of tourists and people that may or may not have been homeless. If you end up here somehow, order a PBR and then move on, but I wouldn't seek it out.
author: Lauren D.

description:
Best jukebox in town!

This bar is just a neat little spot, off the beaten path. I could sit here and people-watch and drink for hours! Interesting crowd, but not sketchy. Friendly, competent bartenders.

Bonus - if you stay late on a slow night, you can pick the jukebox music and swing dance on the empty floor!

Stop in here for a drink, stay for the neat decor and warm atmosphere.
author: Dawn S.

description:
Due to some rather gross experiences with JUST a little too much alcohol, bars have never been quite the same for me. Apparently my tolerance didn't get the memo that HELLO! - I'm Welsh!!!! Welsh tolerance! Welsh tolerance! I come from a long line of Dylan Thomas es.....Richard Burtons and I should by pure genetics be able to drink any guy under the table. Admittedly this theory still needs more scientific research and has resulted in one too many moments curled up in the fetal position, praying (seriously) for the pain to go away, and for the taste of last night to creep back into my unsettled stomach, but hey...what theory doesn't have some flaws? 

Since I'm no longer a bar regular - I have high standards for those that I do visit, being that I'm perfectly sober and able to fully digest every aspect. 

And so Zam Zam easily achieves a well rounded sober four stars.  I came to Zam-Zam for my roommates' birthday last night and had a blast. I loved the Middle Eastern theme, dark lighting and interesting Arabic architecture throughout. The graceful arches of the ceiling are beautiful, and act almost as a sound barrier between each of the two sections of the bar. We were able to hear every witticism we uttered - we're a VERY witty bunch, every random question from an obviously wasted older gentleman who enjoyed quizzing us on every juke-box song, and every drunken slurred birthday toast that was made. 

The lowish ceilings and friendly bartenders help create an intimate and casual setting, and though the juke-box could be a little louder, it oozed the rich textured vocals of Frank Sinatra and jazz classics, while still allowing people to talk.  The crowd was relaxed, glad that it was Thursday  and there was no 'who's that?' scene.  I'll definitely return ...and maybe even bring some of my good old Welsh tolerance, which apparently has been hiding out at Trax - after a brutal up-chuck scene on their dance floor.
author: Jessica T.

description:
"Come fill the cup, and in the fires of spring - the winter garments of repentance fling."

Friends took me here tonight. Persian friends.  
They have been coming to ZAM ZAM for years.  

They told me that there used to be a another mural on the semi-circle ceiling similar to the one behind the bar. They said the new owner had had it painted over. I asked why. They just shrugged their shoulders. "Don't know." They sounded very disappointed. I was too. I would have liked to have seen the ceiling mural. One of my sons is a mural artist, so I'm always looking to see what is out there that was done years ago - - I guess I am a mural anthropologist!  Is there such an animal?

There are brass pipes (for smoking who knows what?) on a shelf over the doorway that look like they have been there a very long time.  We arrived in mass right after Jason R's film was over. There was only one bartender in the small bar. I thought it was going to be a long time before we would get a drink, but no, she was fast. Managed to keep all the glasses around the bar filled and got new drinks for the 15-20 new patrons that had entered the bar all at once.

Very Persian decor. My Persian friends like it. Must be authentic.

I, being an Irishman, drank Guinness. Beer from Dublin hits the spot . . . . .  even in a Persian bar.  

Had a good time.  Cozy, friendly place.
author: Rachel C.

description:
I loved this bar when I lived in the neighborhood 10 years ago. It was everything you wanted in a low-key atmosphere. Unique and friendly, an anomaly of Haight St. We visited it Saturday night for the first time in many years with a handful of folks celebrating my friends birthday, walking into a basically empty bar at 11 p.m. on a Saturday night. The staff was inhospitable to say the least. The neck tattooed door boy and neck tattooed bar boy served up more attitude than drinks to the several paying customers that now filled a previously empty bar. Standing out outside 30 minutes later I overheard the two making hateful comments about everyone in the bar. When 1:15 a.m. rolled around they escalated the agro instead of asking folks to finish nicely. I was not drinking and got special treatment with "you don't even have a drink, get the "eff" out". Being the sober person in the crew I navigated my 12 peeps out of the bar peacefully. Standing outside we see the other 2 or 3 people in the bar that were not part of our crew get into a physical altercation with the Zam Zam staff. 

This reminds me why I left the Haight 10 years ago and rarely leave the beautiful south of market area where hateful little neckies would never survive.
author: blue r.

description: A funky décor (see pic) with old radio and cash register, laid back barflies, and a relaxed bar wench. All things I like about a good dive bar. There was plenty of space at 9:30pm on a Sunday which added to the stress-free surroundings. There's also no cell service in the bar, so you're forced to be social instead of burying your eyeballs in your smart phone. It's a dive bar so we didn't try any mixed drinks and stuck with straight shots from a liquor selection was better than the average bar.
author: Brian U.

description:
Aub Zam Zam was the second stop on our Haight Street bar hop.
This place is really cool. Sort of a mix between Vegas style bar and 60's dive bar.

If you can manage to find a table, you will enjoy this spot as the locals entertain you with their stories and drunken antics. As a matter of fact I think ONLY the locals come to this place. The drink I ordered was well made, but the place didn't serve food which only made my stomach growl with anger as the evening wore on.

Also, don't worry about the fact the bar has a 10 year old kid working the tables. I think he's the owner's kid and he has a TON of stories about the bar and the people that come there.

This place is definitely on my lists to stop at for a drink whenever I'm in the Haight.
author: Black K.

description:
Great bar spot, I've made my way over to Aub Zam Zam occasionally when the Alembic is too crowded.  There's usually plenty of room at this bar, and the drink prices are reasonable.  Their wells are reasonably priced and pretty stiff, which automatically makes this bar great.

I was less than sober each time I've visited Aub Zam Zam but was able to maintain a level of clairvoyance to appreciate the great atmosphere and the cool semi-circular bar.  The bartender was quick with our drinks, and intimate conversation soon followed with other patrons.
author: Eric L.

description:
My dream bar would have friendly bartenders, a well-mannered and attractive clientele, clean bathrooms, piped-in pleasant smells (seriously, how many times has your bar experience been ruined by some foul odor?), good music, decent parking, and would serve coffee and liqueur drinks. Yes, I know, this is probably too much to ask, but a girl can dream, right?

Zam Zam has enough of my dream criteria to be a very good bar. It's charming and has a chill but friendly atmosphere. Yes, parking sucks, the bathroom could be better, and piped-in smells are still a fantasy, but I've met some cool people here, the bartenders are awesome and they make a mean coffee and bailey's with whipped cream.
author: Susan S.

description:
My only experience with Aub Zam Zam was quite drunken, but you know what? I'll be back at some point.

My friend and i started our night at Magnolia where we had a couple beers. Then we went up to Alembic for some cocktails. And on our way back down we randomly decided to stop at Aub Zam Zam because my friend claimed "This is where Anthony Bourdain said they have the best martinis!" And despite the general consensus that Anthony Bourdain is an asshole, we stopped in.

For some reason, we were both under the assumption that this was a hookah bar. It's not. We were also under the assumption that the inside would be more spacious than a hookah tent. It's not. But the bar intrigued us, and we both got martinis, dry and dirty. We let the bartender do his magic, and they were actually pretty good martinis.

But like a good Stephen King novel, this review is not about what it started out as. No, this is not entirely about the drinks, it's about the people and what happened while we were there.

My friend and i were talking when suddenly one of the other bar patrons appeared right between us. He offered to buy us any drink we wanted, which...uh...weird. Weirder still, he told us he had been debating between us or another couple (apparently he thought were were dating), but he went with us for reasons too drunken to understand.

My friend got a shot of whiskey, and i declined the offer because i had to drive us home and had enough to drink already. Well, he wasn't very happy to hear that i would not accept a free drink. He pestered us about it a lot, small talked us for far too long, and finally when he realized that i was unwavering (thanks for that personality trait, mom!) , he gave us (me) $20 and told me to do what i wanted with it.

Well then! This was awkward. It was nice of him, but it was really strange. I didn't touch the bill, but the bartender was pretty happy to take it off my hands. I am pretty sure he gave it back to that dude at some later sober point. God willing, i won't ever have a more interesting experience at this bar.
author: Phuong M.

description: Ran across this place while shopping on Haight Ashbury with family who was here visiting from out of town!  We LOVED it, very dark with old school candles on the tables and excellent martini's.  I don't drink gin, the bartender made it clear my drink was NOT a martini, it was a DIRTY VODKA...LOL  Prices are cheap, $7.50 for the best martini I have ever had...We will be back for sure!
author: Linda N.

description: Lord, if you have your lost ways and need a friendly reminder of how much character your people can thrive with... hobble on into this drinking den and we'll update you on the status of our relationship: committed to the sort of thing you're missing up there -- a former Czech porn star bartender pours martinis with eye contact and a laugh that transports you into both the past of disco rollers and into your (near) future of taking heed to the hope of Sam Cooke's Cupid on the jukebox draws back his bow. Lord, if you haven't heard her say, "Last Call," say hello to your First Love.
author: Jon A.

description:
A true San Francisco classic, AZZ feels like an escape to the past when the jukebox blared Dean Martin and Sinatra and martinis were a standard drink of choice.  

Aside from the great staff and good cocktails, the best part of AZZ is the mixed bag clientele.  The type, size, and vibe of the patrons seems to be very random which, of course, makes this place that much more intriguing.

You come here for the cocktails.  They have a simple, but decent bottle beer selection.  Avoid the wine.  It's a very limited selection and it's not very good stuff.
author: Mike B.

description:
Ok, is there a bar in San Francisco, in this day & age, where you can say "Are you looking at me?"...?!!

I went into Aub Zam Zam following the Bluegrass festival, for a restorative cocktail -- sure enough , I got an excellent martiini & relaxed in the very enjoyable Arabian vibe of the decadent bar. 

But -- soon enough -- a talkative woman arrived in, to disrupt things -- annoying, to be sure, but soon enough, she called me, "What are you looking at ??"  --  really?? "What are you looking at!!!?" -- It's been at while since I encountered such a situation...  I inquired from the regular guy next to me -- apparently, she' s the wife of the proprietor -- interesting.... (Unclear to me how I managed to attract the unwelcome attention. Nevertheless...)

 Very disappointing. I like the place , but really, you cant walk into a bar being prepared for a riiculous (potentially hostile) "Jersey Housewives" rude interaction with the owner's wife...!
author: donal c.

description: Bizarre and interesting place, worth the atmosphere. The place is not particularly clean, the service is not very good. They only serve alcohol, no food, and it's cash only. Also, when I was there, there was a (very very calm and sweet) big dog hanging out inside, tied up to the bar. But if none of that is a problem for you, it's a fun, out-of-the-ordinary bar, with interior decor that will make you feel like you're in another country.
author: Alexa A.

description:
This would be a 5 star place but the martini Nazi died and ever since that day it just isn't the same place.

I miss how the old man would kick yuppies out because they wanted some shi-shi microbrew. He would say, "What you really want is a martini!" And if you said, "No," he'd kick you out.

I used to drink so much here that sometimes that bartenders would get my drink if they saw I was on a date.
