Also, if a regular passed away and "the crew" was here, they would pass out free shots in honor of a fallen friend. The last time I had a shot like that was when Gil who liked to read "fictions" passed away.

What a fucking great bar!

I'm sober and in LA right now, and boy do I miss those good times so much.

Fuck it, 5 stars even though the old man is dead!

The martinis are superb. You get that fine sheen of thin ice on top of them. My usual was a Hendricks gin martini, up and dry, no produce. I could just ask for the usual.

Zam Zam, I miss you!
author: Jim B.

description: When i got there in the late afternoon, the bartender was having a chit chat with her friends, it was like an all good time party. I ordered one drink that was supposed to be a happy hour special for $4. For the time being there, I had a conversation with one of the patrons who was progressively getting incoherently drunker and embarrassing. I wasn't feeling so well so after i drank my drink cause it hit me pretty hard as i drank on empty stomach. I had a few glasses of water and left when I felt better in a couple hours. The bartender overcharged me and acted like a total fucking bitch as I left. Her exact words "Good luck on your hunt, hun" WTF?
author: Natasha B.

description:
I'm usually a beer drinker, but I do love a good cocktail every now and again, and this is just the place to satiate that thirst. 

When I first checked this place out, I really liked the old-time decor on the inside. The round bar is a nice touch as well as the Middle Eastern architecture. It really feels like I'm going back in time. They make their drinks strong, and there are usually very friendly people inside. One time I thought I was being propositioned by a much older woman [see: cougar], but she mentioned her husband, so I can assume she was just talkative. I also really dig the jazz music on the jukebox.

On the downside, they have a severe lack of beer on tap. There's no tap at all, actually. They only serve bottles, which is fine, but they also only accept cash. And that's why I  gave it 3 stars. It's 2011, and even the fake speakeasies take cards. Catch up.

This is a nice bar to go on a first date.
author: C D.

description:
I really like this bar. It's got ambience, friendly bartenders and a great jukebox. The location is in the heart of the Haight, but it's rarely too touristy. 

Good for locals, for dates or after-dinner drinks. A bit pricey ($14 for a glass of wine and a gin and tonic), but very pleasant.

But what the heck does "Aub" mean?
author: Kim C.

description:
Solid bar with lots of bottled beers to choose from.  The liquor is well-stocked and the bartender was quite attentive.  The crowd was very mixed this last Saturday night.  

p.s. They take cash only with an ATM machine inside.
author: Lisa R.

description:
Still a favorite spot... Bartender during the week is great... Great happy hour.
Makes traversing thru all the street kids well worth it:-)
author: Jack P.

description:
I'm just not feeling this place. Its usually way too crowded and too small. They're known for their gin martinis, but mine was only fair- I asked for it dirty, and they skimped on the olive juice. I wanted it San Francisco Dirty! But instead got Colorado Springs Dirty :( Fair drinks, boring, yet crowded atmosphere- just isn't my scene. This place would be a better hookah bar than a regular bar.

You're leaving me disappointed Anthony Bourdain.
author: David D.

description: Went here tonight. Was, to me the best looking cocktail bar in Haight. Not too busy. Room at the bar and the nicest bar tender! We were in town on our honeymoon and the bar tender couldn't be more accommodating. Knew how to make THE best dirty martini and Bloody Mary's. Will defiantly be back again before we go home. Only 4 stars cos the drinks were so potent I needed some food to soak it all up. Would have stayed longer if there were tapas or some kind of snacks.
author: Stacy B.

description:
First hearing about the Zam Zam Room on No Reservations SF, I knew exactly what to expect. It was the 3rd stop of the great Tatyana Visit '10 and most of us are plastered. 

The place is a SF landmark and is absolutely one of a kind. The interior has a mis matched Middle Eastern feel to it w/ murals and small wicker tables in the back. I say miss matched because the juke box plays classic rock/blues/big band and nothing else is reminiscent of the region. If people don't know, this bar is known for their snarky bartenders who demand that you, "don't order anything stupid." As opposed to "Hi, what will you have?", the bartenders will bark, "What do you want?" 

That night, we were celebrating Tatyana's glorious visit to the bay so rounds of shots were on the menu, but it seems like every round is a mix of starring down, compromise, and sweet talking. 

"No, you're not getting that shot, you will get this one instead." 
"Um....no I want that shot. 
"There are other places to get that shot, they are right out the door." 

Awesome. Despite, my Friends' disappointment, I'm sure they make a good Martini, Manhattan, Old Fashioned. I recommend coming here w/ a healthy alcohol tolerance and sense of humor.
author: Angelo F.

description:
I don't know if anyone has mentioned this, but Aub means water in Persian. And Zam Zam is a well that is located 20 meters east of the Kaaba, in Mecca, the holiest place in Islam. So "Aub Zam Zam" means Zam Zam Water, the water that is considered sacred that comes out of the zamzam well. The story goes that Hajar, wife of Abraham, was with their infant son, desperately seeking water, being a hot dry dessert valley and all. The son, Ishmael, started scraping the ground with his feet and water suddenly sprang out. To this day people go there to collect this sacred water. 

That being said, and the fact that alcohol is often forbidden within state-controlled Islamic countries, I think many people are missing out on the irony of the bar's name.

Anyway.

I came here the other night post Citrus Club and pre BRMC @ GAMH. Some Johnny Walker Black Label did me just fine, and my friend got some beer I think. A jazz 4 piece was huddled in the back corner doing there thang. Not too crowded, not too dead. In and out. That is all.
author: Ken L.

description: This place isn't a trendy mixology mecca like some other places on the block (I'm looking at you, Alembic) but still makes good drinks at a fair price. It a more local feel - which is just euphemism for "you can actually get a seat". Dogs are welcome, and present, even late into the evening. Service was a bit slow with only one bartender, but she was very nice and not at all frantic in spite of being busy. The decor is some strange combination of eastern dive bar + martini lounge. Good for grabbing a drink on a date, or a small group of friends.
author: Chris C.

description:
This bar is and was known as the Persian Aub Zam Zam and was infamous for the now deceased owner and bartender, Bruno, who was prone to throw out customers he either didn't like, or didn't have enough seats for at the bar, saying, 
         "Tables are closed, TABLES are CLOSED!"
or the always popular, 
       "We don't need your kind here, there's more your kind down the street, DOWN THE STREET!"  

Well known for repeating things twice for emphasis,  Bruno was fond of saying,  "Don't call it Mount Tam!  It's MOUNT TAMALPAIS!  You probably  have a basketball hoop on your garage!"   Also:   "This used to be a good neighborhood; now, it's a bad neighborhood" was one of his oft-repeated refrains.  

Now the bar is just a sort of regular neighborhood bar, but the ghost of Bruno lingers on...
author: H.A. ..

description:
There was something in the air here on the Saturday night I visited.  The bartender was doing a decent job channeling some of the attitude of the infamous Bruno and still made a couple of fantastic manhattans and a damn good martini.  The other times I had been in here was in the middle of the afternoon on a weekday.  Quite a different scene.

It was a chill evening.
author: Theron L.

description: Old school San Francisco at its finest!!! Kundan is the best bartender there...she is always welcoming and knows her shit when it comes to making a great cocktail .. Manhattans yes please!!!!
author: r m.

description: Really cool old bar on Haight with alot of history.  The origional owner would throw you out if you asked for a Vodka Martini.  He might throw you out for ordering a Gin Martini, "There is no way to make a Martini except with Gin.", he would tell you.
author: G. G.

description:
This used to be where the old Martini Nazi owner ran the bar. It used to be funny watching him run people out if they either ordered a beer or sat down somewhere other than a bar stool. I got bounced once for asking for a few extra olives after the drinks was made.  Honestly, I couldn't help laughing as I walked out.  He would go, "You should probably go have a beer down the street.  There are plenty of options."

Giving 3 stars for nostalgia sake. No idea what the place is like now.
author: John K.

description:
If I would have reviewed Aub Zam Zam a few months ago, the place would have gotten 4 stars for its solid drink selection, half circle bar, great juke box and being host to Naked Photo Hunt - the finest electronic bar game around.

I went into Aub Zam Zam last Friday and to my horror found no Naked Photo Hunt machine in the corner near the couch. No more NPH!?? I stuck around for a drink but it just felt like something was missing when I couldn't stare at photos of naked girls dressed like 1970s porn stars and try to find what was missing. A bra strap? A misplaced head band? One heel taller than the other?

NPH, I miss you. And as for you Aub Zam Zam, 3 stars until NPH makes a comeback!
author: Hannah L.

description:
Why are you reading this.  Don't you know?  Poseur.

Happy hour at the Persian Aub Zam Zam is great:  cheap drinks, friendly conversation, and all the pretzels you can eat.  If they had beer on tap, I'd give them five stars.
author: Eric L.

description: This place has a nice feeling to it.  Great atmosphere & very friendly.  We had a woman bartender both times.  Happy hour is the best.  Very reasonable & she makes a wonderful Manhattan.  Nice selection of whiskeys/bourbons.
author: Donna W.

description: Dog face stepped on by track suited patron. Has whiskey though. Sad experience. Would not recommend.
author: Nick C.

description:
I didn't know Bruno nor do I give a shit. I like the bar just the way it is. 

The prices are appropriate. The bartenders are friendly and good at what they do. 

For example, we were in there one night when a guy and a girl stumbled in. It looked like the guy had met up with the girl or maybe she was just a lightweight because she was very very sloppy. Long story short, the girl starts rubbing a random guy down under the bar and the boyfriend sees it and starts in with the random guy. Girlfriend yells some stuff and takes off out the bar. Tay the bartender runs out after them. Why, you ask, you shake her fist and tell them never to come back? No, they left too much for their tab. Then the whole bar was laughing about it. Great time.

I like a place with a little attitude and Zam Zam has it, but the people make it.
author: Jay C.

description: I'm sitting inside what I can only drunkenly describe as Aladdin's Palace, listing to Tony Bennett and Marvin Gaye, and drinking PBR (2.50 for a 16oz can) by candle light. It's confusing and I like it.
author: Hannah B.

description: Great SF location! Great local bar! Its old school at its best!
author: Bob P.

description: Zam Zam is one very cool happy hour stop in the Haight.  The bartender was friendly and made a great cocktail (martinis and manhattans).  Frank Sinatra playing on the jukebox....picture from 1948 new years party... Dark and Divey - enioyed the company and the conversation and the overall ambiance.
author: David S.

description: Probably my favorite place in the Haight :) So cozy, with a wonderful jukebox and killer Bloody Mary (make sure to tell them how much spicy you want it...!)
author: Anny P.

description:
It smells like old socks in here.

Also, the walls are done up with these cloth-like wall things, which are very old and look like they have been blanked-on. You know, peed, puked, sweated, insert your own verb in the blanked.

The older gentleman bartender looked down his nose at me, then made me a very weak drink.

The circular bar is cool-looking, but there's much better places to drink on Haight Street.
author: Rachel H.

description:
I'm not the Haight and Ashbury type but I do enjoy a well made cocktail. I'd been past it a million times but never gone in. After watching Anthony Bourdain give it merit, I figured it was worth a shot. 

We were early for a dinner reservation and decided to try it out. Id heard they have awesome martinis here. 

First off, this place is small. Very small. 

When in Rome, you have to try the spaghetti. So here I ordered a Martini. I ordered it with Tito's vodka and my friend with Russian Standard. Both were AMAZING. Ive made martinis at home and none come out well. I've had them at other bars and they never come out well. 

If a martini at a normal bar was an orchestra, one instrument would be louder than the others and just sound awful. At the Zam zam its like the New York Philharmonic playing with Frank Sinatra singing. 

Enough Anthony Bourdain-ish over-the-top analogies. 

Trust me, get a martini
author: Kevin D.

description:
Low-lit atmosphere in this small bar, the decor resembles a grown-up version of Disney's version of the middle east.  Very cool.

Drinks were inexpensive (albeit on the smaller side) and the bartender was very pleasant.

Stop by and check out the mural behind the bar.  You'll likely stay for a few drinks.
author: David D.

description:
Very impressed. Somewhat abrupt bartender, but he made a mean Manhattan. And for only $7!

We ended up here because Alembic was busy and wouldn't even let us stand inside on a cold SF evening. I think we made the right choice by coming here instead.
author: Sachin A.

description:
I don't really know what category I'd put this bar in besides the fact that I like it. Its got kinda a Persian theme going so at first you think its a hookah lounge, but its just a little hole in the wall bar.  However, its not like a dive bar because they have a good liquor selection and can make you a mean cocktail (gin martini=A+). 

Tuesdays they have live jazz music which really adds to the ambiance. It feels like you are chilling in someone's basement bar or in a different era entirely. It just feels very comforting in here, especially after that first drink!

Side note: One of the bartenders has the cutest Samoan that wanders around.
author: Alixandria F.

description: We stumbled across this gem in the Haight accidentally and were pleasantly surprised. The bartender was as a bartender should be -- knowledgeable, efficient and with a little attitude. The decor is amazingly bizarre and there was a giant dog in the corner. This will be my new go-to place in the area.
author: Rachel M.

description:
Very cool vibe here complete with beautiful, young martini sipping locals and a small jukebox with an eclectic music offering.  With this clientele, I was certainly out of my element (beautiful and young) but felt very welcome and I was chatted up frequently. It's dimly lit, surprisingly just the right number of patrons, and had the real old-school Persian vibe.

This is one of the places on Haight that provides good refuge from the panhandling, weed-dealing insanity taking place outside on the street.

I was here three times in the five-week span of my visit to the Bay Area. I expected the bartenders to carry on in the tradition of Bruno and braced myself to not get served, but the bartenders were all very nice and accommodating. In respect of Bruno's larger than life legend, I ordered only gin martinis which were done very much the right way. Five martinis and 45 well spent dollars later, I stumbled back into the very disjointed and bizarro trappings of Haight Street. Things are no longer peace and love in the Haight (try as it may), but at the Aub Zam Zam bar, it could be 1950 or 2010 and it would still be the same.
author: Alec W.

description:
If you could take The Dresden room and squeeze it into a space the size of your bedroom with a horse shoe shaped bar then you'd have Aub Zam Zam. 

The bar tenders are friendly enough and the crowd is a mixed bag like most other Haight street joints. I can't remember ever having any drinks that made me do a double take, but they generally aren't offensive either. 

During the course of a night where your ship is steered into many ports, if you find yourself on the upper haight this isn't a bad place to pull into. If for nothing else than to see this tiny little space and sigh wishing there was enough room for Marney and Elaine.
author: Len S.

description: I had spent a few Jack Daniels soaked hours here while visiting  a dear friend last year.  This year, when said friend had to cancel our rendezvous because of work commitments, I decided to head down to Aub  Zam Zam all on my lonesome:  Stepped in a rainy Monday night and it was just as good as I remembered:  An atmospheric, glowing red cave of a bar with a splendid curved bar and other charming accents, including some pretty rad wall art.  One of the best juke boxes on the west coast is stocked with blues, 50s RNB, and other old school faves.  I had a couple of well prepared gimlets and chatted with the friendly bar keep and a motley collection of travelers and locals.  An absolutely ace watering hole.
author: Stephanie D.

description: Nice spot but small and they only had one bartender on a Fri night. So we (about 6 of us) waited over 30 mins with hands waiving cash and the bartender never got to us. She was obviously busy but it also didn't seem quite like she saw virtue in serving a lot of drinks. I got the sneaking suspicion it was more about the display of attitude and cool factor. The music was too muffled to hear. The lighting was a bit bright. I might go there on a weekday afternoon but probably not on a weekend again!
author: Maryam M.

description: A bar I look forward to frequenting whenever in town.  It's like walking into a watering hole 50 or 60 years ago. If you go here you better not ask for bear...instead get your fill of classic cocktails like manhattans, old fashions, and whiskey sours.  This place is always a must when I'm in town, I recommend you stop by.
author: Josh B.

description: I love bringing friends here when we are in the Haight.  The atmosphere is dark, with a "let's get ****faced" with no pretensions- vibe.  I personally enjoy the dogs.  A little divey but refined, like a fine red box wine.  If you like it dark, divey, with good liquor drinks and various oldies on the jukebox this is the place for you.  Pull up a stool at the bar with some locals, some bikers, and few out of towners.  Bring cash!
author: Liz S.

description: AZZ is my favorite local bar.  Being in the Haight I think it is important to have a bar that is a good mix of regulars and tourists (even if the tourists are just from the other side of town) and AZZ is that.  The bartenders are friendly, and the bar is small enough and curved in such a way that it is conducive to talking to strangers.  The juke box is filled with mostly jazz standards. Also, the decor has not changed much since the 1930s.  I admit I often imagine a dapper gentleman lighting a cigarette for me at the bar.  Though I am glad this is not possible.  My only complaint is the fact that it is carpeted - any bar with carpet losses a star as far as I am concerned.
author: Tia B.

description:
I confess, I only braved this place because Anthony Bourdain told me to. And I'm so happy I did. I've walked by it a million times and always thought it looked a little seedy from the outside. Couldn't be further from what it is. 

You walk in and are at the bar which takes up about 75% of the space. The interior is very interesting, kind of arabian nights like but with an edge to it. The juke box has good music and it's not too bright, but not too dark either.

This is the kind of place you just sit at the bar, or if lucky enough hang at one of the few tables. It's a great spot for a low key night with a couple friends/buddies, I don't suggest going with a large group because it's just too small inside. There's only one bartender and no cocktail servers. But...there's a full bar which is always a plus and most importantly, no attitude!!!! The bartender was awesome and made a mean martini!! I do not suggest ordering anything froofy, just stick to the basics beacause it's not a fruity/girly drink kind of place.

Cash only, but there's an ATM inside.
author: Kandace K.

description:
Best jukebox in the City. Lots of jazz, blues and some rock-and-or-roll. Love to come here on a saturday. Listen to Bob hold court with the regulars and load up the jukebox with my favorite tunes. If you hear "Don't Fence Me In" I'm probably sitting in the corner with my wife. (Update: the cd it was on was removed, but it's still good...)

Would give five stars, but the prices are kinda steep. But for the atmosphere and attitude I don't mind spending a little extra. Also love a bar with real history. Feels like a stroll into the distant past.

I also hate TVs in Bars. There isn't one. Watch yer sports somewhere else, dude. Listen to the Jazz!
author: Jason G.

description:
Several inaccuracies in a previous review:  The late Bruno Mashoggi died in 2000, and his bar was called the PERSIAN Aub Zam Zam ROOM.  

The joint was founded by Bruno's father in the early forties, and Bruno learned everything he knew from his father.  

He only made Gin martinis, because he believed that the Martini was invented with Gin (he's right).  And when you insisted on a Vodka martini, whoosh, out you went.  (Same with ordering a Manhattan with anything but George Dickel).

I was a habitue of the place in the 80s, and never, ever, ever DIDN'T get kicked out (not through any fault of my own - Bruno would wave his hand and kick out half the bar on a whim).  

One time (pre-cell phones), I asked if he had a payphone.  He told me that he used to have one, but his dad ripped it off the wall in the forties.  I asked why.  He told me that his dad caught a sailor in there with "a dame."  I laughed, and got kicked out.  

Once, a friend insisted on a Manhattan made with Jack Daniel's. Bruno suggested George Dickel. My friend wanted what he wanted - WHOOSH!

He told me once that he closed the bar in the 70s - for years.  

If you looked seedy, or too hip, or drunk, or were being silly when walking into his bar, he'd suggest that you go to the bar next door (the Achilles Heel).  

He was a character.  Here's his obit http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2000/12/03/MN133570.DTL
author: Cheesemonger Jeff D.

description: Dive bars don't get much better than this.  Oh why did it take me so long to find you Zam Zam?
author: Sean H.

description:
Of all the gin joints in all the city...

Ok, so that cliche's been beaten to death already, but you have to admit Zam Zam's got some Bogart-caliber retro class (with a similar reverence for traditional cocktails), not to mention the exotic Persian design (and yes, I know Persia != Morocco, but still).  In other words, the perfect bar for my tastes.  So where's the 5th star?  I'll dish that out on the day I actually manage to get a seat here.  Because unlike Rick's sprawling Cafe Americain, AZZ is a real postage stamp of a spot.  Just that big circular bar, a few tables, and the tiny, dark back room.  Of course, for those lucky (or just plain early-arriving) few, the intimate size makes the experience all the more classy.
author: Wes M.

description:
what a shit hole. exactly the kid of dump a middle age guy like me needs after having his brain shaken in the alembic by the younger loud kid crowd. a very nice, not too loud place to sit and get blasted. this is the kind of desperate joint old men go to drink and cry. i loved it. 

i went there with my much younger cousin who couldn't keep the contents of her drink in the glass. i chalk it up to youth and inexperience. it's a pitty we couldn't have sat there and gotten blasted on the cheap, but the old guys were looking at me like what the hell was wrong with me bringing in a rookie.

next time i'm goin in with anthony bourdain.
author: scott c.

description:
Persian Bar, What - GO HERE FO SHO.  This is one of my favorite bars of all time.  The best of all my worlds - I bet this is what a bar in Iran would look like if Iran was cool - better yet I bet this is what bars looked like back in the day when it was the Persian Empire. 

The place is small and never really seems to be crowded.  I love this place.  The name alone aub zam zam (look it up) - are you kidding, what a perfect name.

If I ever own a bar it would be like this one - kinda...
author: Siamak S.

description:
I could go on and on in an obnoxious nostalgic way about what this place -- actually called the Persian Zam Zam Room -- used to be like when Bruno was still running it - but why should I?  It's so much better now.  Nonetheless, let's say three cheers for History - and I'll give you the run down.

For decades the place was owned and run by a fellow named Bruno.  Bruno would not serve you if any of the following was the case: 
(1) You were not seated at a stool at the bar (yes, the place always had chairs and tables, and you could always sit at them, but you'd never get a drink);
(2) He didn't like the way you looked;
(3) He didn't like the way you talked;
(4) He didn't approve of your drink order;
(5) Any little thing about you rubbed him the wrong way.

Now, Bruno would normally not overtly refuse to serve you, he would just ignore you until you went away.  It was amusing to watch.  Bruno was crotchety.  He preferred to make martinis, and little else.  My personal Bruno story went like this:
Me:  "Bruno - what kind of gin makes the best martini?"
Bruno: [in gravely irritated voice] "Aaah it's all the same shit."
Me:  "Ok, I'll have a Tanqueray martini, dry, please."
Bruno: "You don't want Tanqueray.  It's crap.  Bombay Sapphire - that's what you want."

Bruno died about a decade ago, may he rest in peace.  One of his nephews, I am told, bought the bar, or inherited it, or something.

Nowadays, the drinks are stiff, the bartenders are friendly, the crowd is diverse and unpretentious, the place is comfortable.  If I go out for drinks in my neighborhood, this is the place I go, 90% of the time.  I am partial to Wednesdays.
author: Joe C.

description:
Last call for alcohol.....finish your drinks please!

Now, I don't understand this, why would they kick you out when you spend large amounts of money here. Can't we just hang out and sober up? Why the need to kick us out, we tip very well.

After getting pretty much kick out of Gold Cane, we decided to come here. Not much excitement here when you come here with a bunch of drunk friends. 

And guys, we don't care if a place has romance, all we care is alcohol and cheap woman.OK OK OK OK...maybe I'm still drunk. No cheap woman, just cheap drinks and strong pours. You don't want me drinking at home now, do ya?
author: Stanley K.

description:
A great little place with some soul, Zam Zam has a very excellent jukebox selection, with blues, Hank III, and jazz. 

It's  a good place to go if you want to be able to sit down and talk to your friends - not too loud, and there are always places to sit, but it's also not totally dead. You don't have to shout over anyone, and the proportion of smart, cool people to the annoying types I generally "haight" is also generally pretty high. Yuk yuk, yes I use that joke way too much.
author: Heidi G.

description:
This place is kinda rad, even though the drinks are a bit expensive.  They make a decent Irish Coffee, and if you ask them for suggestions they'll come up with some exotic stuff to try, like Creme de Menthe and Soda.  Their jukebox is mostly older R&B, Blues and Jazz, but for some reason, every time I walk in there someone is playing "the Payback" by James Brown.  

You could say its suited to an older crowd though.  There's no tv's, so you can't watch the game or anything like that.  

Also, its really red on the inside.
author: Gopal R.

description: I go to bars. Often. I usually know exactly what I want, but I'm always open to suggestions. Tonight I brought a friend from out of town who was fairly indecisive; she has for years ran her own bar in Washington, so she was really just looking for a recommendation for this bar as she loves tryint new specials. Not for nothing, but for what it's worth, I was with 3 other very attractive women. I asked the bartender if he had any recommendations. His immediate response was "Find another bar." So I did... an amazing bar to be reviewed elsewhere. I will never walk in this place again.
author: Shannon Marie B.

description:
Did you know that the original owner of Aub Zam Zam would throw out any man who didn't relinquish his barseat to a woman? And that the same fate awaited anyone who ordered a vodka martini?

Now, I may not agree with those policies from a vodka-drinking / modern-world / feminism point of view, but I do have a certain admiration for someone who sticks to their guns in such relatively harmless affairs.

So how do I know about these policies? They're not still enforced, as the original owner has passed away. A beautiful and trivia-laden woman took me to the Aub Zam Zam recently (I'm a pretty damned lucky guy), and filled me in on the backstory. It strikes me that without this history, the bar could be mistaken for just another oddly decorated and slightly rundown joint, especially as the years since the owner's passing slip away. Aub Zam Zam is more than it lets on.

My one visit to the Aub Zam Zam was just enough to order a gin martini, no olive, with a twist (wonderfully delicious, by the by) and sip it in the wonderfully old-school atmosphere of the back room, decorated and architected in a distinctly Persian motif. 

I believe I'll return to the Aub Zam Zam at some point. That martini really was fantastic, and this coming from someone who's doesn't select gin as a first, second, or third choice alcohol. Now if someone had some insight as to whether "Aub Zam Zam" means anything, or is just a really cool name, I'd be happy to hear it.

Update:

From the same afore-mentioned woman, I've learned that "Aub Zam Zam" means "fountain of youth", according to Herb Caen. Told you I was lucky.
author: Paul B.

description:
This place is a nice retreat from the hustle and bustle of pre-pubescent pan handling, counter-culture socializing and overpriced shopping that the Haight, in some cases, has always been and in others, has become. 

Persian Aub Zam Zam seems a bit out of place, but I suspect it has always seemed a bit out of place. I suspect that any place that gives you a burning desire to be color blind so you can see it in a black and white film noir style of the 40's and 50's, that specializes in martinis (gin only, because anything else isn't really a martini) and has a gentrified feel to it would seem a bit out of place in this neighborhood........which is precisely why it is such a fantastic bar. 

Want a quiet dark corner table to cozy up to your date? They have them , tucked away in the back, away from the bar. How about a mixed crowd of professional conversationalists who will keep you entertained? Just hop on a stool at their horseshoe shaped bar (I LOVE horseshoe shaped bars) and the conversation will flow. Want a place that makes you feel like you have escaped the here and now, even if just for one cocktail? Stop in and take a vacation from your daily routine. 

5 Stars. That's all.
author: Drue C.

description:
It's kind of unfair for me to rate this place, since I haven't lived in SF since the mid-80s, so I've never had a drink there that wasn't poured by Bruno. I was, however delighted to see Tony pimp for this place.

Yes, I witnessed the abuse, and mentally recorded some of the greatest put-downs every uttered... "those people, they must be from FREMONT, I'll bet they drink BUD, from CANS" etc" (after tossing some people out who tried to sit in "that awful little room").

"Jack Daniels? That's a Madison Avenue drink... you want this..."

If it's half the bar it was, it's not to be missed.

Oh, and Bruno told me the bar was built by his dad, and the mural was painted by a friend of his dad's. Dunno if that's true, but that differs from another story on here.
author: P H.

description:
came here the other day with my yelp gurlfiend Kimby T. and we both had a weekday off. So decided to go to the Haight and have a drink at around 430pm. Came here and hopped bellyed up to the bar. I had the champagne and she had a mjito. YUMMY.
We were talking to the bar tend and got on the subject of vodka them we started taste testing on all of the vodka's that was ever so nice of him. It was only about less than 5 people in the bar, but it was still nice.
Great place to chill.....
PS-
They have the Bong Bottle Vodka from Amsterdam.....Damm that's smooth vodka!
author: Der Maibaum L.

description: What a rad lil bar we stumbled upon!! My bf and I just finished up getting tats over at Mom's and we felt the need to numb the pain a little. We found relief as soon as we sat down here. I love historic places, especially old bars and this hits the nail on the head! The place legit has not changed since the 40's. They even still use the original cash register. No POS systems here! The bartender gal was super cool and very helpful in suggesting her favorite local bars for us to check out to avoid the touristy stuff. Matter of fact she even wrote them down for us and we really did follow it and hit up a few places on list before heading back to the hotel! Lots of colorful characters are patrons here. We chatted up some gemists visiting from France, a local older gentleman who I later found out was in his 80's because he ended up at the next bar we stopped at that the helpful gal wrote on the list of bars, and a few others interesting (in a good way) people. The bartender treated the whole lot to a round of some sort of jager like shot I can't remember the name of and we all toasted together. As out of towners we felt sooo welcome here, probably the most welcome out of every bar we had stopped at during our week visiting san fran.
author: Sara K.

description:
I rarely go to SF but it was my best friend's birthday so I decided to grab the fiance and head up and try my best to enjoy the city. 
After we ate dinner, the 15 of us walked down the street to Aub. I have never been in here before and was surprised to see it was a different setting from most bars. I have switched from liquor to beer so I was hoping to grab a Sierra- but they don't have beer on draft just in the bottle. With a huge vat of us coming in, I expected the staff to be rude and pissed but the bartender was really nice. He smiled a lot with everyone and wasn't your typical A**H*LE bartender - so that made my night. 
If I am ever seen in the city again, I will probably drop by this spot again just to enjoy a quiet and relaxed time.
author: Kelly T.

description: Pricey martinis ($9) but a fun vibe for a first stop pub crawl..
author: Hb H.

description:
It ain't everyday that you can say that you have a legitimate Persian bar in your home town. Mexican Bar? Scottish Bar? German Bar? Big F-ing deal.

Show me another bar that represents an Axis of Evil nation. North Korean? I think not. Hell, if you came up with a Sudanese or Pakistani bar I'd give you props.

But we have our own Persian bar with as much culture and history as any other dump in SF. 

Top that Indonesians!
author: Jason R.

description:
"Ya gotta have a little ugly..."

So said the punked out girl at the end of the bar.  She was overhearing my friend Andrew's conversation with the bartendress about favorite fetishes.  We all broke up on this because.. ya know.. it is sooo true!

Aub Zam Zam is just one of those perfect places for a cocktail and convo with pals.
author: Jim S.

description:
This is a place I hope that the three main - current - inhabitants of The City DON'T find - the yuppies; the hipsters; and the grunge (sp?) crowd. Where are the NORMAL, yet old-school cool folks??

This place has had a coat of paint since Bruno passed away, and the prices have gone up, but the place still feels as if Bruno is around the corner. This is old San Francisco. Yes, he made a good martini... and yes, he made a few other things... 

On my half-dozen visits there, he kicked out many a pretender who didn't KNOW HOW TO ACT!!! Could the current folks adopt the some of his spunk? OK, a few of Bruno's verbal classics... now, he was clad in black & white, with a vest, and a HUGE belly.

**Hipster, upon walking in: "Hey, can I get a margarita? This is so coooool... I'm from LA."

Bruno: "Good. Why don't you go back?" Silence. Hipster - meekly: "I heard that this place is cool..." Bruno: "You'll want to go to the bar on the corner, its the best bar on the block." Silent treatment; guy left.

**A group sits at the bar, and one grunge dude starts cursing. Bruno glares, "There is NO CURSING. THERE ARE LADIES PRESENT!" A few minutes later, a woman actually orders a non-martini drink! Maybe it was a Manhattan or a Gin & tonic. Same woman tries to light a cigarette... and Bruno deftly & carefully whips out some matches, and lights her cigarette for her, ala the Bogart days? He also gives her some old (vintage?) wooden matches, and some are floored.

**Three yuppies walk in, and try to order some girlie drinks. Bruno: "The tables are closed. You'll want to go to the bar on the corner..." Yuppies: "But we heard its cool here..." Bruno: "Come back on a Monday Night... WHEN ITS RAINING." They left, dejected.

**I'm at the bar with a voluptuous brunette, and the mood is quite & respectful. I look at Bruno, and ask him, "What did you & [Herb] Caen talk about?" Everyone looks at me in horror... as if I would get kicked out at any moment!

A pregnant pause.. was he waiting me out? Then, Bruno goes into a little dissertation about their conversations on opera... or was in classical music? One preferred Vaugner (sp?) ... and the other, someone else.

Anyway, I wish one of the newer gang would occ. toss out some louts, in respect to the history of Bruno & his ethics. Curse at a woman, act uncouth? Toss em out!!! And maybe... no pina coladas? Order one, and you're out!! hahah What say you yelpers?
author: M Z.

description: This is my favorite place to bring ppl when the come visit me. They make some wicked good hot drinks like hot toddies and irish coffees. The bartenders are cool, the ambiance is great, and the scene varies
author: Ross H.

description:
Bruno was sort of the Bobby's Owl Tree of the Haight. The first time I went with a friend who just loved to get kicked outta this place. Said friend-at-the-time, loved to start out a not so promising Friday night by asking for a Vodka anything and receive the mighty finger wagging toward the door, "OUT!" It was a badge of honor to get the Bruno Boot. Then we got wise to what we were missing out on and stopped making so much trouble. 

Still a fun spot for the "Haightoisie." Though the barkeep are more sedated compared to the cantankerous Bruno, it's still worth a stop for it's decor, history and mui strong cocktails. You won't find any unleaded here!

4 Sir Chuck Barkley's
author: Johnny C.

description:
My friend and I wandered in here on a whim.  It's not a dive - it's clean.  It's "quaint" (read: small) and romantic (read: dim lighting).  But certainly not a dive.  Good booze, friendly 'tenders, reasonable prices - 2 Orange Grey Goose cosmos for $15.  I liked the music, but it was old jazz of which I know little.  When we walked in, it was mostly women, but the crowd turned over within an hour and it was all men.  I have a feeling that it frequently turns here, but maturely.  Not pretentious at all.  

Oh, and if you want to take a date here, there are little tables tucked away in dark corners, if you catch my drift.  :)
author: Jessica M.

description:
My absolute favorite bar in SF. Actually wait, no, it might be my favorite bar anywhere. I love you Aub Zam Zam... you bring out the gypsy in me, if I weren't alone when I went here I would have grabbed a tambourine jumped up and started dancing. 

Wham Bam Thank You Aub Zam Zam!
author: Lynn C.

description: For bars in the Haight this has got to be my favorite.  Good people, and a killer jukebox.  The best part is the amazing service and tasty cocktails!
author: JT N.

description:
I'll admit, I'm something of a daytime drinker. I can't tell you what this place is like in the night, but during the day, it's a hell of womb. 

I dig it. 

If you're going there during the day, do yourself a favor and bring sunglasses. If it's bright out, the cave-to-kaboom lighting differential from inside to outside is brutal. 

Also, I used to meet my girlfriend here when we were seeing each other on the sly. It's got just the right vibe, and pretzels.
author: Roy M.

description: The bartender was an older man. We told him that we saw this place featured in no reservations and he told us prior to the taping he had never heard of Anthony Bourdain. Now he watches all his shows and even read his book. The place is kinda creepy because the interior is dark and old, and there were two old men at the bar..but it has been around since 1941. Drinks are strong!
author: April Rose D.

description:
I felt like I was walking into another time upon entering this establishment  this past Saturday afternoon... the cavernesque dimensions of the bar, along with the dim lighting and throw-back music made me wish for a page boy, some proper stems and a spunky pal attitude to accompany me to the horseshoed shaped bar.

Then I could have tapped my well shod toe on the brass shoe rim of the bar, while eyeing the tourist eyeballing me and said, "What are you looking at pally?"

Aub Zam Zam was a refuge in a storm of the Haight tourist machine... the tourist machine in a neighborhood which is striving so hard to find it's way back to another time - Aub Zam Zam has successfully negotiated that time travel and landed right where it belongs - twenty-some odd years before the "summer of love" smack in the middle of the 1940's.

I swear while we were there we overheard the bartender say that Aub Zam Zam had survived three wars, two earthquakes and hippies... *grin*

Not to mention that the drinks were cheap considering the neighborhood... also poured strong... and, the conversation was good - I had an engaging discussion with a gentleman at the end of the bar about living in New Orleans (something I used to do.)
author: Kate R.

description:
This is my favorite bar in upper haight ... quite possibly in the city.  Its cozy, charming, dark and the vibe is exceptionally chill.  This is a great place for a date since the lighting is perfectly flattering and the noise level doesn't overpower the conversation.  If it wasn't so old school, the decor could certainly dance on the line of tacky ... and while the bathroom is desperately in need of a make-over, I just can't help but love the place.

I prefer the less crowded times either during the week or late, late on the weekends.  Its a lovely hidden little safe haven.
author: Sarah K.

description:
I am in an abusive relationship with Aub Zam Zam.  The bartenders treat me like poo, sometimes they verbally abuse me, and yet I keep going back.  My friend is trying to get me to leave it, but I love it too much.  I think I can change them, make them nicer and better people.  Who knows, maybe they are good people, but not so nice to little old me. 
I digress. Can't beat the atmosphere: feels like you're in the love child of Star Wars and Saudi Arabia... in a good way.  Strong drinks, little nooks to  tuck into and solve the world's problems, and always good tunes from the crazy juke box.
author: Kate S.

description:
I don't know what it is about this place - I love it.  For all it's weird decor, awkward and sometimes rowdy crowd, distinct smell, and poor lighting...I love this place.

The bartenders are great, the music is chill, and the drinks are 'basic' done right.  It's great.
author: Girls Named Cherise C.

description:
I am very, very sad that I never thought to go to Zam Zam while I still lived in San Francisco (a quick walk away no less).  It's small, has lovely deco style decor, and the bartender gave a gesture of approval at my drink choice (a negroni).  

It did not hurt that the first person I saw upon walking in was an older gentleman with a white mustache, spectacles, and a straw hat sipping a martini.  Charming.
author: Katie S.

description:
Last night, I went to Zam Zam and it sucked. There was some hippie-looking bartendress who so did not know what she was doing. She'd spend minutes looking for her strainer, and made awful-tasting mojitos and Saphire tonics. So, stay away while she's working there and my 5-star rating will make more sense.

When the wholesome guy is the bartender, Zam Zam probably has the best mojitos in town (he spends like 10 minutes making each one, and does all these intricate, arcane things to them). He's also good (as his the girl who normally bartends with him) with martinis, Manhattans, and gin and tonics.

Zam Zam's probably the best-looking-without-trying-too-hard bar in town, and it probably has the fewest annoying people within it's gorgeous arabesque confines. One night, there was a scary Mediterranean sailor type of guy there with his shirt halfway unbuttoned and a Japanese tourist girl on each side of him (each stroking his hirsute chest and giggling). He looked, as I said then, like he enjoyed fucking geese. No, I don't know what that means, really, but it was really really funny at the time. Uh, my point was: that guy was the scariest person to be seen within Zam Zam, which ain't so bad. Goosefuckers, I can handle, as long as they're not loud, obnoxious, or wanting to dance. And nobody in Zam Zam ever is.
author: Ben P.

description:
It was so incredibly late. Birthday girl said she wanted to kick on for a bit... sometimes she forgets that some of us are 9-5 workers and actually had to get up at a reasonable hour. Its only Thursday. 

A guest picked this bar at the Haight called 'Zum Zum', its across the road from Milk, she said... in the neighbourhood, close but no cigar for you m'dear.

We found Aub Zam Zam after some clever detective work i.e. speaking to a waiter from a nearby restaurant. Three blocks later we were outside the hole in the wall.

Loved the decor, and mood of the place. There was a jukebox by the door with some classic tunes installed. All we were missing were the burlesque dancers.

I was just a touch cautious since you never know what the crowd would be like at such a pretty place. They turned out OK, completely fine actually... but what's with the people in sailor hats?

Our group of 7 found a table at the back... too many people crammed into a space better described as exuding Parisian charm. A must re-visit with a hot date (when such occasion presents itself, sometime soon I hope).

Ordered one basic mixed drink (vodka cranberry), and it was very well done. That should have told me there's a cocktail mixologist in the house. Note to self - go back for a martini or three. 

Had a great time, and really was a shame that we didn't get there till so late.
author: Joyce L.

description:
What a funny little establishment.  I get the feeling it's well-loved by its regulars, and I can understand why: very intimate setting, very moody lighting, and a sort of non-standard floor plan make it seem like the kind of place that could be "yours".

As a random visitor, though, I found it a bit barren.
author: Oliver N.

description:
I'm so mad that I've been living working in the Upper Haight for a year and didn't know this place existed. The two silver doors are hardly significant amongst the wide array of storefronts on Haight Street and the common tourist wouldn't even think to come inside, but I'm pretty sure the folks at Aub Zam Zam like it that way.

Absolutely no natural light can be found inside the bar, unless someone walks in from the street.  The colors are dramatic...deep/bold reds and black, with a Middle Eastern influence for the decor.  The bathroom was relatively clean, which is practically unheard of at a bar in this neighborhood (Alembic is new so it doesn't count).  And the jukebox was my favorite.  The selection is heavenly...from B.B. King to Louis Armstrong to Nina Simone to Aretha Franklin.  I might come back just to listen to music...forget about drinking.  And speaking of drinks, I got drizzz-unk in a hour and a half, off of two drinks.   I felt quite tispy after my Lemon Drop (a little too tart btw) and so I actually watched the bartender make the second drink, a Vodka Tonic, and it was like 4/5 vodka and 1/5 tonic.  So strong, but surprisingly tasty?    

Anyways, great neighborhood bar.  Nice atmosphere, friendly bartender, divine jukebox, and strong drinks, without the tourist crowd.
author: LaSha G.

description:
After getting drinks at another local bar, my boyfriend and I stumbled into this place. The dimmed lighting and music were sultry and sexy, at least that was what I thought the night I was drunk on Haight St. 

That night I thought I hit the jackpot of local bar coolness. 

(Drinks minus dinner= drunk, yes, oh yes)
author: Amy J.

description:
Yes, I'm totally guilty of the fact that Anthony Bourdain told me about this place and sent me here in search of an honest martini. I just wanted to get that out of the way. Although I can't believe I've never been here because I must have walked by this place 1,000 times in my 27 years on this earth. Ridiculous.

Aub Zam Zam is the bar. The same bar it was 50 years ago or, for all I know, 100 years ago. It's the most cliched thing I could ever say on here, but "they don't make 'em like they used to".

What do I mean? This place is so...darn...simple. Yet elegant and interesting just the same. First of all - it's just a bar. It's not a lounge, club, restaurant, cafe, pub, public meeting space, or bookstore. It was always meant to be just a bar and that's all it is. There's nothing else to do here. Seriously. Second, the drinks are serious, strong, and fairly cheap. Third, the bar is shaped in a semi-circle. This allows you to actually SEE and maybe even CONVERSE with the people you're sharing this relatively small room with. A curved bar - an ingenious invention. Finally, the place has character. Character from age, character from Bruno the dead bartender, character from the persian and/ottoman decor and mural present all over and character from the old-school juke box playing old-school music.

They really don't make 'em like they used to.
author: Tolga E.

description: Aub Zam Zam is a great bar! It means Holy Water...!! They have very high quality mixed drinks, although I always get the sparkling. The bartenders always make me smile. The jukebox has the best jazz lyricists ever. I adore the mural behind the bar, and the old school bw photo that sits behind the register. I heart my neighborhood for this very place. ;)
author: Mei F.

description:
I come for the jukebox.

I have songs I play every time I go in and I am sometimes successful in getting my husband to dance with me :)

The drinks are good, almost always get martinis.  Chocolate, sour apple, dirty, it dosen't matter.  High quality booze, interesting people, nice enough bar tenders.

Its 2 blocks from my house so we go quite often.  Probably would not trek across the city for the drinks or atmosphere, but like I said before...I come for the jukebox!
author: Claudia M.

description:
The last time I was in the Haight on a Friday night, someone in my group asked why we never party in the Haight...I I looked around and counted a dozen or so anarcho-hippy squat punks in the immediate block. Yeah, that's why.

Fortunately there are a few nice respites in the area. Zam Zam is one of them. We had planned on starting the evening at The Alembic (a few blocks away), but the place was way packed. So we ventured to Zam Zam.

All three times I have been there, Zam Zam has been virtually empty. Which is kind of sad if you are alone or in a small group, but kind of awesome if you want choice seating and no wait at the bar.

It's a classy place. And they make great martinis at an amazing price... 6$ for a dirty. Wow! Come here to get away from crust punks (if only for an hour or so).
author: Trey F.

description:
I walked in with a friend on a Sunday evening thinking it won't be crowded, just getting one drink, i'm in and out. The bar was empty except for 5 old men sitting at the bar listening to the reasonably attractive bartender tell an amazing story with her voluptuous, enormous personality.  She saw us, so we politely waited for her to finish her chit chat.  We waited...and waited and then left.  She sucked ass.  

Other than that, the bar is pretty cool with a good atmosphere and music at a non-ear drum bursting decibel level.
author: Denise C.

description: What a gem!  Super friendly bartender (not in a creepy way), reasonable prices, strong drinks and amazing juke box.  The juke was filled with old music from the 40s-70s of all genres (jazz, blues, country, rock, etc.).  Extremely happy a friend of mine took me here while I was in town!
author: Nicole B.

description:
Nice low key hang out with a straight forward bar and no BS drinks. Seating is limited but interiour is cool. There is seating in back with a couple of small tables but not for large groups unless you like to stand. Staff is friendly. 

A favorite SF hangout.
author: Lance H.

description:
Zams has been *the* post-finals drinking spot since starting law school.  Prior to law school, it was just a fun, chill place to grab a drink.  But now, NOW, it holds an even more special place in my heart. It has nursed my sorrows post-exams and made me forget about them in one-drink flat. 

The bartender/co-owner actually remembers the fact that I am in law school.  He pours a very generous drink and makes a fabulous Hendrick's martini, garnished with a slice of cucumber-- he knows his stuff.  He refills the bowl of pretzels or snacky-snacks consistently and when he asks me about my life, I think he really means it.  

Last time I went, I was feeling a bit chilly so he made me a delicious hot toddy.  You can't find a good hot toddy north of the Mason-Dixon line but here it was, on the upper Haight.
author: Sun K.

description:
I love this place for it's semi-circular bar, top shelf liquors and history. Used to be the owner would bartend from noon to 2am, and refuse to serve anyone that didn't order a martini, AND only if they ordered it correctly. That is, no dirty martinis, no dry versus wet martinis and no preferential treatment.  When the old guy passed on, the new owners took a more lenient stance on who they'd serve.   It's got great ambiance, and feels like old school San Francisco.

It's small, and can get crowded at the height of drinkin' time (9-midnite).
author: Jon F.

description:
This place epitomizes why I love my neighborhood, the Upper Haight.  The bar is visually, for lack of a better word, cool.  The room has a nice, relaxed feel to it.  I can come here, sit at the bar, and have a few drinks.  Or I can sit at a table with my friends and have a few more than a few drinks.  The martinis are fantastic, but all other drinks are far above par as well.  Plus, I can come in jeans and a sweatshirt, or I can come in a suit if the mood strikes me.  No one cares--and this is why the Haight is such a comfortable place to live.  The neighborhood generally, and Zam Zam in particular, is a great place to just be what you feel like being.  

Back to Zam Zam--I know the history of the place, with the notoriously strict Bruno kicking out all those not worthy.  I wish I could have experienced this, but alas, it was not to be.  I can say now though that the bartenders make a mean drink, and it is just a comfortable bar to knock a few back in.
author: Blake W.

description:
Five stars when Bruno was around. Where is that framed photo of Bruno when he was in the military that he kept by the register? We used to go to the Zam Zam all the time and were never kicked out. You just needed to know Bruno's limits. The tables were closed, Limit your drinks, behave in a reasonable manner, don't curse and all was cool. 

The new Zam Zam is hit or miss.  Sometimes if you call a particular brand of liquor they will pour it the first time, but change it back to the well on your next round unless you remind them. Its louder and livelier than it was when Bruno ran the joint. Is that good or bad? Its hard to tell. The bartenders I have experienced seem nice enough. I appreciate that they kept the mural and decor.  The juke box still has nice music.

Gone are the days with Bruno serving Herb Cane sitting on the stool on the end of the bar. I'll just have to accept that fact. Thank God they kept the original concept and didn't turn it into a sports bar.
author: Amanda L.

description:
Things I like about Aub Zam Zam:
1. It was designed at a time in America when all things Arabian were cool - you know, the time of Elk's Lodges and Fezes.  I love the decor.
2. The bartenders are consistently amiable, interesting, service-oriented, and fun.
3. They play old jazz.
4. It's a block from my house.
5. From the outside it looks sketchy so it keeps the less committed bar goer out.
author: Chad W.

description: This is a great place to go if you are looking for a nice conversation over drinks.  The lighting is semi-low, there is absolutely no food and there is no menu.  You should know how to order your drink because the bartender always knows how to make it and the selection of spirits is superb.  It looks a bit outdated, but it is hard to find a spot in the city where you can have laughs over a couple manhattans and not to have to outyell euro-techno-beat.  If you are out because you want to be seen, don't bother coming here.  We don't want to see you.  Stay on Polk st.
author: Yevgenia F.

description:
I ditto all the positive comments about this bar and have one thing to add: 

If you go in, ask to see the old picture they keep behind the bar. It's taken on New Years sometime during the 40s and the interior looks almost exactly the same. It's awesome.

Update: They allow dogs on a case by case basis. This information just increased my alcohol intake significantly.
author: Cat S.

description:
A well made Manhattan is an elusive creature.  Honestly, I never order them anymore.  A properly made Manhattan goes down smooth and makes your brain hum Dean Martin tunes, therefore a crappy Manhattan is twice the insult.

If you've never had a well made Manhattan then stroll into Aub Zam Zam next time you're (for some odd reason) in the Upper Haight and order one.  You'll see what I mean.
author: Mark G.

description:
A nice and unpretentious bar, with good service and good prices. You'll run into a few colorful locals (I just almost wrote "lolcats"...), and if you're lucky, they'll show you a cool new book they just picked up or tell you a story about something that happened 30 years ago that they very vaguely remember. You won't run into a crowd of loud and obnoxious dudes in backwards baseball caps and flip flops (they head up to Hobson's Choice). 

Not the kind of place you go to for an "amazing time", more like the kind of place where you just go.
author: kay v.

description: I felt like I walked out of 2009 into 1969. This was the dark red pimp bar. Bob, our bartender, was totally chill and cool. He said the owners found the mural on the wall and built the bar around it. They also have a really old cash register that's older than the bar. I got a beer on recommendation, and it wasn't that great but everything else made up for it. Looks like a lot of locals (not the hippie homeless types) infused with travelers like myself. Everyone at the bar was cool and it was like we were all drinking together and chatting. I'd stop back here anytime I am in the area. Beware, they do not accept credit cards.
author: Devon A.

description:
Such a random place. I love their little cocktail glasses that are filled way up to the top. No room for olives or any other nonsense. Tasty and strong. This place is for classic, well made drinks. If you are not sitting at the bar you will need to slurp a little down before you take your drink back to your table. 

It never seems crowed.. but always kinda busy.  Odd i know. This place is just what you need after you OD at cha cha cha just down the street.
author: Dustin H.

description:
Love that it feels like a cozy humming warm red womb of a bar. If you can score a little table, it's a great spot to people-watch.

The jukebox is excellent - and extensive. Bessie Smith, Billie Holiday, Merle Haggard, etc etc. Real cutefest.

Although, the drinks are a bit pricey. And the crowd a bit off, but perhaps it was just the night I dropped in.  One friend described a patron as the creepy diaper-wearing garbage babies from "Nothing But Trouble"
author: Emily S.

description:
AZZ is my regular watering hole.  Good drinks, good atmosphere, good bartenders, quiet enough for conversation, lively enough to be interesting.  If you are looking for a meat market, or a "WOO PARTY!" place there are plenty of other places on the street for that, but for a good drink with friends I think the AZZ is hard to beat anywhere in the city.

The focus is on straightforward cocktails and as such most of the space behind the bar is dedicated to booze, although they do have an adequate selection of bottled beer and wine for those that are not in a cocktail mood.
author: Zac K.

description:
Wait?!  This place is still open?  I heard that Bruno died, and I am clearly out of the loop that it's still open.  Not too sure how I feel about it still being open -- sort of like the Dead continuing on without Jerry -- but I guess you gotta keep on keepin' on.

Back in the early 90's, I got turned on to this place and I felt very late to the party -- granted I was about 60 years too late even by then.  In any event, I had been schooled about what to say and not say, and do and not do.  For example, gin martinis only.  And don't ask for anything special (like dry, or shaken, or dirty or something dumb like that).  Also, NEVER let your date pay.  Also, don't ask questions.  Stuff like that.  The first time I went, my goal was to be there for a full drink and not get kicked out.  I made it, but I'm pretty sure I didn't have much fun as I was so tense and worried about poor Zam Zam etiquitte.  The martini's were seriously $1.50 each (but very small).  Who's gonna complain about a small pour?

Seriously old school juke box, but I never had the courage to play anything.  By the way "the tables are closed" so don't bother sitting in the back.  

I miss you Bruno.

Any truth to the fact that Bruno owned the majority of the real estate on Haight street?  That was the going speculation.
author: Brad P.

description:
I thought the Zam Zam was a breath of heaven this past November 26th, as we scurried through light rain on Haight street. We were really only there to visit some sexy-time stores as me and my husband were on our honeymoon.

FIrst of all, we needed to pee. Bad. I think of becoming a customer strictly for the purposes of toilets as an inevitable but worth-it reality some days. Especially at a bar where you can think of the bathroom as a 5$ charge and the drink as an on-the-house treat.

Second of all, our Makers and sodas from the prior night, and our champagne drizzle were all singing tiny anthems in my mind still. Not hangover melodies, but sweet fuzzy songs of love and weddings and money trees, and honeymoons. So, it being about 4pm, was time for a drink.

Third. Jukeboxes sadden me these days. Probably because I moved away from the super-cool jivester hymns of Echo Park and Portland, and wound up again in the high country, the gold mines, where meth moms and angry old ex-playboys run bars like one might run a strip club, with only the slutty in mind while programming the jukebox. (That statement does NOT include the Mine Shaft's or The National Hotel's music machines) So I am SICK of Christina and Pink and Pearl Jam and Martina McBride. A real unique solid jukebox is worthy of paying for a million drinks. This one had Tom Waits, and old weary blues-people, and I am sure a little Nina Simone, and probably even some French perfume. 

So we stayed. A couple in the corner was playing Scrabble. My Makers and Soda was divine, and my husbands beer was cold and something not available in the picturesque dive bars of Nevada City. The bathroom was red and small but clean, and the shelter  from the rain was exceptional. The giant painting behind the small circle bar caught my daze for some time. I dreamt of Persian clothing and wrecking my stockings, and thanked God for Martinis and those who love them to death.
author: Adrienne S.

description: After stumbling around the city for 2 days, my husband and I wanted to sit down and have a drink. We got a seat right at the bar. The bartender was extremely friendly and made us some special cocktails. We spent the next few hours having a great time talking to everyone and enjoying the atmosphere. We were told that Anthony Bourdain stated that this was the only place in Haight-Ashbury worth going to, and I have to agree.
author: Megan G.

description:
Warning: the drinks here are very strong. I found that out the hard way after my date decided he had enough to drink and headed back to his house, leaving me alone with two full Belvedere martinis. I had been enjoying the dark, secluded atmosphere and it would have been a shame to let those lovely drinks go to waste, so I proceeded to finish them solo at one of the side tables. 

My date stumbled back to Aub Zam Zam a half hour later, which made me happy until I found out he came back not for me, but for his credit card. Oh well, at least the martinis were delicious. I'll be back again... with better company, of course.
author: Jessica C.

description:
I think one of the reasons that this place still looks so good all of these years later is that Bruno used to kick your ass out the minute you sat in the seats by the wall.  

The first time I went in was with a group of 6, and only one person in the group (not me) knew we were gonna get booted when we sat in the back and asked for beer.  In retrospect it was pretty funny.  It was also funny because in general you want guys like me in your bar.  I like to spend money on drinks and tips, and I don't stand on the furniture.

Now that Bruno has left us, this place is kind of like most places on Haight.  A bit crowded, the crowd skewing to the younger side, and pretty fun.  They still pour a good Martini, and that's probably what I'll be there for.
author: Nelson W.

description:
A friend told me that the old owner used to regulate who was allowed to sit in different areas of this place to the point where it became a badge of honor if one was permitted to sit at the bar.  If that tradition were still alive it would give this place a little something extra.  But now its past its prime and, like the Haight district itself, lost its edge.  

That said, its still a chill little bar with an interesting persian theme where you can relax with friends over drinks...and contemplate the fact that, like Britney Spears, bars can become has beens too.
author: Jason S.

description:
This is a stellar cocktail bar.  It is hard to really sum up what makes it so great.  The nice, drink-knowledgeable,happy, cool bartenders.  The wide variety of cocktails you can choose from.  The funky interior.  The jukebox that only plays jazz (some blues).  The friendly neighborhood vibe.  The reasonable prices.  The uber mellow atmosphere, even on crowded nights.  The list goes on and on. 

This is a cocktail bar, so if you are a beer person your selection is limited (but with decent options to choose from).
author: Kristin S.

description: SInce Alembic was a wee bit crowded, my party ended up here. The second we entered I was like, "this is that Bourdain place"  So I ended up having 3 awesome Gimlets. The best I ever had. Great decor and the calmness of it all just added to the beauty. Next time I go to the RVCA store I'll grab another.
author: Marvin O.

description: I came back with a group and had a more pleasurable experience. It was early in the evening and we were grabbing a drink before dinner. The bartender was much better than last time and the environment seemed friendlier. Still expensive but it's a touristy area. I would come back for a pre-dinner drink, probably not for late night. (But I like to dance and this is just a bar) -- The Long Island was made perfect! Better than I've seen anywhere else in the city but the bartenders are hit and miss. Cash only.
author: Chris I.

description:
I live really close to Aub Zam Zam and have never gone in because it really creeped my out that there aren't any windows in the front.  Silly, I know.  So my brother insisted we go there because he lives in the Haight too and was disgusted with me that I had not been.  

I have had a vodka tonic at many a San Francisco bar and I have to say, this was one of the best ones I have had.  That's all I can really say.  We meant to go for a drink or two and stayed for three or four.  Oops.  

Don't go expecting anything fancy (or windows).  It's just a great, chill neighborhood bar that makes an exceptional cocktail.
author: Lauren H.

description:
Where do you go when you can't get into the Alembic? HERE!
Landed here with small group of friends when faced with a 45 min wait to get a drink at Alembic up the street.  Fast talented bartenders keep the pace and spirits up.  Didn't try the food.   The atmosphere is nice, classy lounge feel,  murals on the wall.  Busy - you will be lucky to get a seat here.  Reasonable priced drinks.  Thumbs up.
author: Brent F.

description: Bruno the Martini Nazi is dead. He left the place to the people who lived upstairs. Everyone comes here pretending that they are drinking with Bruno but 99% of the people in here now would have been kicked the f*%# out by him. Its a beautiful place to see but if you think it is the same joint Bruno ran you are highly mistaken. It is a bar where people live out a fantasy of drinking with the illusion of Bruno. A bar in reality where their yuppie butt would have been promptly kicked out of.
author: Johnny B.

description:
I've been drunk a lot before.

I know, if you meet me now, you'll think there's no way.

Part of this "streak" was comprised of visiting a bunch of places my good friend's significant other randomly thought of without reservation.  She'd say something like "Let's go to Aub Zam Zam!" and my friend would tacitly consent while I sat quietly, knowing nothing better to suggest.  About 3 hours later, we'd be in a cab.  My friend would be yelling loudly and quoting his favorite movies, his girlfriend would have her eyes half closed with a smile on her face that said "I'm REALLY wasted" and I would be somewhere between the two.  Ultimately I awoke the next morning without a clue of where we'd been.  

Fast forward one year and here I am again at Aub Zam Zam.  

I enter and it all comes flooding back.  

Even though a friend prompts me to order a martini, I had already remembered that the martinis where why we had gotten so intoxicated the previous visit; we drank them like beer.  The martinis here are delicious and this was when I didn't think a martini could be delicious.  Our bartender, while young, seemed very skilled at mixing and it showed as she poured out a perfect looking martini, the booze in the glass peeking over the brim, appearing as if one more drop might cause it to overflow.  The martini was excellent.

I was tempted to order another martini, this time with Level instead of Chopin but realized it was only about 9pm and I should avoid reverting to previous visits (at least for now).
author: Steven R.

description:
I might as well be 12 years old, but Zam Zam is still a throwback for me -- perhaps to a past life in which I was a brooding, tall man in a gray suit sitting at a similar semi-circular bar, looking glassy-eyed through a cloud of smoke at the crisp, bow-tied bartender serving me a dry martini with a twist of class. That's what I remember, at least, when I hang out here.

The ambiance is great. The music is better. The bartenders are magnificent. Sit at the bar and take it in.
author: Chris L.

description: What a great bar!! We stopped in here just to use the bathroom and stayed for 3 drinks! Such a good spot with great music and a mellow atmosphere. (I did go on a Sunday though) it could be more popping on Friday or Saturday. The Blondie bartender was so nice and made some mean drinks. If I'm ever in the area I'll be going back for sure!
author: Sheila P.

description: I give ZamZam's four stars for the location, atmosphere and hospitality!! My boyfriend, never being, wanted to stop in for a drink. I was in AHHH over the Persian theme and intimate setting. Lots of culture and was given the history of the mural on the wall!! Very interesting!  (could very well be because I LOVE middle eastern settings) It was very dead when we went on a Saturday afternoon, however, it had a Cheers like feel to the bar, "where everyone knows your name!" We also saw newbies like ourself too stop in for a drink. It never got busy, then again we didn't stay long enough to see it get busy, however, the bartender said it was busy earlier that day and gets very busy at night. They turned on the juke box later in our stay and played it at a perfect volume in the back ground! I would def hit up that place again while visiting H&A!
author: Michele A.

description: My third favorite place to drink in the city... AZZ has a very chill vibe, and a very friendly staff. Although the patrons tend to be an older crowd, there are some nights where you can catch a mix-bag. This is a good place to settle and have a good conversation after a big dinner.
author: Ray H.

description: My uncle Patrick loves this place.  He loves to go in there on a Friday afternoon after a long week at work, talk to Bob and hear the old timers talk about cool places to hang in the city. If you are true old San Francisco or have a true love for this city, this is the place for you. Not just yuppie hipster love, Lifers. They all sit around the bar, talk to Bob, probably the coolest guy ever, shoot the shit and enjoy a stiff drink.  Isn't this what cool bars should be? A place to feel comfortable after a long day/week at work? what can I say... Bob you are the best, you make my uncle Patrick enjoy life.
author: Danielle W.

description:
we were originally going to hit up milk but they had a tribute band performing so we walked down the street and stumbled upon aub zam zam.

this place rocked our world.  drinks were cheap and super stiff and the bartenders were a riot.

fun ass night which led to a killer hangover the next day.  damn you zam zam and your hefty pours. lols.
author: Wilafur L.

description:
Old school decadence! 

A beautiful, u-shaped bar with classy barkeep. Rich tones and velvet curtains adorn this classic retro Persian cocktail lounge.

 Cocktails done ala 1950s (strong and correctly). The bar allows you to see everyone sitting at it, which is nice for conversation with new people.

It was one of my favorite finds on my first trip to SanFran!
author: Kera E.

description:
I really like this place, but it seems a little more of a scene than I am used to.  Not much to it... horseshoe bar with lovely barkeeps that were very friendly.  I had an incident in a poor to judge stupour that made my friend and I believe that we were in a more liberal environment than we were, and admit I am shocked that we were not kicked out for what we did.

Yes, I will remain stoic and vague in regards to that, but albeit it is simply a bar in the Haight, plus one star for being classy with my ill decision.

Cheers!
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
I unfortunately (fortunately?) never had the chance to experience the wrath of the old owner, but I guess that's neither here nor there. The Zam Zam of today is a very cool spot; it's intimate, with dim lighting, a red decor, and a very cool round bar on your left when you walk in. And, the martinis. By god, the martinis... Herein lies Zam Zam's true charm. Authentic, stiff, how you like it, and let's just say it'll take a lot for the fine bartenders to let you know you've had your fill...

Many a fun night here, and bonus points for being in my neighborhood. Another reason to love the Haight, and one of the few haunts where I pay no attention to the beers on tap while I'm there.
author: Drew S.

description:
The king of vodka martini.  They totally don't jip you on the alcohol portions.  I'm not alcohol expert, but I really their vodka martinis here.  

Kinda dirty inside, can be noisy.
author: Dong T.

description:
Went here for a "girls night"...  a good time was had by all...

A Thursday night and it got crowded fast... my girls and I luckliy scored some premo bar seats.  And Martini's were poured.... and consumed...
Once it got hoppin' it did get a bit loud, but not horrible. 

We all had a variety of drinks...I started with a classic Cosmo, and ended with the not so classic... Green Tea? Or something like that... I can't remember because of all of the alcohol it contained.  Delish.

Luckily my man arrived with a sober mind and wheels... cause there was no way this lady was driving anything home.   I might have even gotten a ticket for reckless walking in heels!  

I hope to return someday, (with a ride home... !)
author: Jennifer K.

description:
This is probably one of my favorite bars so far, in my 3 years here. It's small, with dark rich colors on the walls and has persian decor. The semi-circle bar is backed by an odd but good painting, and of course - a decent top shelf selection of booze. The juke box plays old jazz, among other music, the bar tenders are uaully nice and professional  and I've only been there once when it was too crowded for a seat at the bar (which is the best seat in the house). 

Definitely try it out for an early evening drink during the week, I think the weekends are busier (too busy for me). 

Also, appreciate the hilarity in the stories from the days of old...!
author: Alexa S.

description:
I am pretty much over the bar-hopping scene and more into drinking beer at home and watching the Sopranos, but this still remains one of my favorite Haight afternoon haunts, and is definitely not the place for you if you like Hobson's Choice.

Sadly, I doubt that many folks know the rich history of this place; the martini nazi, his father, how the new bartender played b-ball with Dubya, however, you can find all sorts of articles (even Bruno's obit) if you Google the place.

This is the perfect spot to hit after you have been weaving in and out of hippies for the past hour and if you're in need of a stiff drink and good conversation.
