My mother actually spotted it on a visit to SF 3 years ago and she recommended it to me.  Turns out, my boyfriend found the place through a friend years ago and became enamoured himself.  A definite must-see!
author: Hannah A.

description:
i grew up on Height and Monosic and i remember when my mom would send me to Zam Zam to fetch my father to come home.  It is a time honored tradition with myself and friends.  

Good cocktails where it is a given you can ask what you want and how you want it.
author: Jai D.

description:
After a leisurely day of hitting dispensaries, Aub Zam Zam was the perfect spot for some refreshing.  We were also keeping with a repeated-name theme, so Zam Zam fit right in with our next destination of Cha Cha Cha's.  Where we were going to listen to our new Yeah Yeah Yeahs CD.
   
   Since it was quite the wait for CCC's, a drink here was necessary.  There was virtually nobody at the bar, and the one guy who was there recognized me as his bartender and bought me a shot.  No complaints there.
   
   I wanted to climb into the painting behind the bar and fraternize with the people in it.  They looked friendly and had tigers for pets.
author: Lea N.

description:
Cool place to get a cocktail in a sea of shoppers and hippies.  

Thumbs UP:  GREAT interior.  Special Morrocan interior and cool semi-circle bar 
Thumbs DOWN:  Expensive and gets crowded on the weekends at night.
author: Jeff C.

description:
The Zam Zam, I could drivel on about the old days, but Helena's nailed the place. An essay I read recently also goes into more detail: http://tinyurl.com/9nbo7

The book is also a great read!

5 stars for the way it was, 3 for the way it is. So 4 on average.
author: jim b.

description: I'm not a huge fan of bars, but this one was okay. Went on a Saturday evening, about 6pm, and it was not crowded or loud - very conducive to having a drink with a friend and some conversation. The atmosphere is fun - Middle Eastern theme with appropriate decor. Very 1950s.  Dim lighting and decent music. Patrons seemed to tend toward the older age range, but I think that makes it more civilized - no drunk raving college kids, basically. Dirty martinis were very good. I'm not usually in the neighborhood, but I'd go back if I was there and in need of a martini again.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
Come for the minaret, stay because you forgot how to leave. 

You've seen this place from the outside.  Maybe you've seen it from the inside and can't remember what happened in there.  I'll tell you what happened: they served you your first real martini in god knows how long, you hit on the bartender, fell over a couple of times and made some unsavory new friends.  You wanted to stay for breakfast but they made you leave.

It reminds me of the fort I built out of carpet remnants and pillows when I was about six, except at Zam Zam there really are scary people outside who want my money.
author: Phil K.

description: $5 glasses of champaign- keep 'em comin! No frills inside, great jukebox- bartender will even give you the loot to feed the box. We accidently made our way in here and found it hard to make our way out. Will be back.
author: Jina E.

description:
This used to be my favorite bar...until a couple of days ago.  I ordered a shot of cheap whiskey, a Boont Amber Ale and a dirty martini and the bartender looked at the drinks after he had poured them and gave that, "um, let's see....let's go with....uh......$18".   I know I am in San Francisco, but I felt I was totally overcharged for the size of the martini (mar-TINI is right).  My next order was another martini and a beer and it was $11.  What gives?  Is a shot really $7?  How come the prices are not consistent?  4 stars instead of 5, but I'll keep the original description. 

This is a hole-in-the-wall bar with a non-pretentious ambiance, a great selection of music in the juke box that is played softly enough to have a conversation.  The best time to go is just before dark on a weekday...or during the day....no tourists, no hipsters....just regular people wanting to have a good time with a drink poured just right by a polite and attentive bartender.
author: regina k.

description: lindsay is the sweetest bartender, even if she is only 5'1".  :}  oh and BTW, this place is haunted.
author: Pickle R.

description:
A few days ago my brother and I waked over to the Aub Zam Zam, and although the bartender made a good martini the place itself looked like hell.  I think that Bruno was a bit heavy handed, but he did manage to protect the place from the ignorant savagery of the Upper Haight.
    My memories of that time evoke a softness of light over red velvet, the dignified authority of the circular bar, and the magic of the twinkling bottles behind it.  All of this created a setting where the holiness of the creation of the martini transported the drinker to a timeless spot, a room in a constructed memory that was so nice to dip into when the grimy monotony of the city street got you down.
   The Aub Zam Zam that my brother and I walked into was a crowded shit hole.  Amateur drunks have kicked in the wood paneling, torn up the fabric on the walls, ground their filth into the velvet floors, graffittied the bathroom, and damaged the furniture.  And there is no sense of a loving touch to the place, or even the hand that tries to heal a wound.  It has been left to rot in the fashion of an abandoned carcass that has putrefied beyond the nibbles of the lowest scavenger.  Like too many spots in the Haight, this place is a good trip gone bad.
author: Buck K.

description:
A lot better since that old coot died.  It used to be the place to go if you'd lamented that you could never get kicked out of a bar.

Still, I've lost Exhibit A for my theory that every Haight Street business owner has a personality disorder.  Rest in Peace, old man.  I hope you're kicking the angels out of that Bar Upstairs, where the tables have been closed for the last 3500 years...
author: V. M.

description: I remember sneaking into Aub Zam Zam about 8 years ago with one of my best friends. An older bartender (not Bruno, as he had already passed away a few years priot), was nice enough, but a little rough around the edges. This place was dark and moody; just a notch above a dive, but no less loved as a local gem. We wanted to feel like fancy adults, so, at 16 (my friend was 21), we ordered dirty martinis. They were delicious and needless to say, after only two of them, we stumbled out of there like angry, old poets and wandered the city in a foggy, distant haze. I returned to Aub Zam Zam two years ago for a gin and tonic. A friend of mine wanted to check it out, and the vibe was exactly as I remembered it, but the drinks were not as good. This place has some sort of history behind it, and you can feel it when you look around and absorb the surroundings. Would I come back? Probably not, but there's at least a comfort in knowing that it's still there.
author: Frances L.

description:
Hey folks! This was the first time I came to this bar and I really enjoyed my time there. Let me break it down:
Occasion: Leopard Print Birthday Bar Hopping!
Arrival time: Aprox. 10:00 PM.
Crowd: Not too much, but it was a particularly cold and yucky night, so it might have been that there weren't much people out.
Atmosphere: Very chilaxing. The lighting in the place is dim, but not so dark you have to reach for you phone and use it as a flashlight. I don't really remember the music, but that isn't necessarily bad as it suggests I could actually enjoy conversations with friends without having to yell at them. I found that to be refreshing.
Drinks: The bartender tending that night was very good and very flexible. He was willing to make drink for us that he never made before. Friends of mine had ordered an Espresso Martini at a bar in NY and asked if they could have something similar. The bartender warned it was the first time he would make it, so to be honest and tell him if we enjoyed it. It turned out AWESOME... we all had at least two.
Size of bar: This place is tiny, but has room in the back for a large group. 

Overall, this would be a great bar to either make a pit stop on your bar hopping extravaganza or a place to chill after a good dinner for some tasty and reasonably priced drinks. 

And what made this places THAT much more amazing, is I had left my cell phone in the bar, so when I called the next day to find out if they had located it, I discovered they had stowed it away in a safe place until the owner returned to claim it. So super cool.

I gave this 4 and not 5 stars because it was the first time I had gone, so I'll definitely  go again to see if its truly worth 5... which I'm sure it will be.
Cheers!
author: Michele H.

description: Great place for a drink.  Usually pretty chill on the weeknights.
author: Ben B.

description: Great atmosphere inside, great bartenders, and a lengthy history to keep it classy! Great place to lose a Sunday.
author: K. C.

description:
Been to this place twice. Both times Brett was bartending.  He is always ready to invent a new and delicious drink, if you are in doubt as to what you want. They have an excellenct selection of liquor. The juke box mostly holds old blues and jazz to make it a very relaxing atmosphere. Clientelle are friendly. There can be some barwide converstions (assisted by the curved bar) or people can keep to themselves. 

Overall, a great place to grab a few delectable drinks and relax.
author: Val C.

description: Great place to chill out. Nice bar setting with lots of drinks that I am not familiar with and the bartender can mix any drinks based on your likeness and it will be beautifully made. I am mesmerized by the history of this place and feeling totally nostalgic.
author: T L.

description:
i haven't been there since the owner died years ago (i guess his son is managing the place now)

i remember going in there back in the day with two friends and watching him throw out the yuppies who would stroll in there randomly. he eventually threw us out after about 45 minutes. 

it was a blast seeing the looks on the customers faces when the old man would yell out "tables are closed" in a rainman like voice and kick them out.
author: Thömas F.

description:
walk into another time! this place is adorable and interesting
i almost felt classy being in here!
author: Jacquelyne M.

description: best little cool bar in san francisco!!! Its a must everytime I come into town
author: Ed G.

description: The hipsters have taken over the ZamZam and Bruno must be spinning in his grave.  Swear words flying all over and a 10 foot python crawling around the bar?  Please bring the touch of 40's class back!
author: Kevin M.

description: This was a pretty neat place.  I went on a Sunday night so it wasn't really too crowded.  The drinks were a little pricey but i had a couple of drinks that I have never had before.  I had a sidecar which was pretty good. $7.  Neat environment and ambience.
author: Michelle S.

description: Very red, cool, vaguely old-school swanky sort of atmosphere.  This place is built around martinis, and that's what they do.  Sure, you could order something else, but why?  It's a cool vibe, and having the bar in a half-round in the room is pretty cool.  A worthwhile stop if you're in Upper Haight.
author: Don H.

description: It's like the teacher's lounge in the high school-esque neighborhood of Upper Haight. Well made drinks & a sexy noir-esque setting (I don't consider this place a dive at all)but without the bullshit that usually comes with most "lounges" in this city. The kind of place where  women are called dames & skirts and all the men smoke cigars.  If I was going to have an affair, I'd have him meet me here.
author: Maria D.

description:
A long time ago in a far away land .. I was told to check out this bar on Haight Street called Aub Zam Zam. The rumor mill had this establishment pegged as a martini bar with a ruthless, snappy, and bitter old man working behind the bar. Although, martinis were his trademark, he made the drinks how he desired. He also choose to open and close the bar at his convenience. He would only allow particular people to come into his bar. If you were not welcome he would ask you to leave or ignore you. There was no such thing as convincing him. Eventually, you would figure it out because he would NOT take the time to serve you. Now you can see why I was so hesitant in checking out this peculiar spot.

As far as the rumors went, they were TRUE~ very very TRUE! The man who owned the bar and the whole damn building, was named Bruno. Aub Zam Zam was his martini playhouse during his lifetime .. until he passed away last year and left the bar to friends (((God Bless His Soul))). Since the new owners have taken over the direction of the bar has changed for the best. The bar seems more welcoming (of course) and they serve beer, alcohol, and wine. Martinis are not a thing of the past .. they do have exceptional martinis but if you want vodka instead of gin it IS possible. The bartenders are HOTTIES too, from what I have seen.

I admit that I do tend to space every now and then but with a jukebox full of jazzy material that I am not into, it is easy to daydream. Personally, I would prefer a little more upbeat music. I really think that this would add to the atmosphere of the bar. I do understand that each place has its own sound but I think they need a new one! It is SO easy to doze off while sipping on your drink sitting at the half oval shaped bar. Speaking of drinks .. I believe they are relatively cheap. Of course, I have had the luck of having many of my drinks bought for me. It is a great place to meet an acquaintanance, a date, or an old friend. They have booths along the wall and tables in the back. The bar is small but it also can hold the prefect crowd. It seems to me that the community still has no clue what the bar is all about or what kynd of people are patrons. The bottom line is this is a lounge bar with a jukebox full of jazzy material that is probably getting more hype now then ever before. It is definitely worth your time to check it out, it has changed over the years for the better! I am sure Brunos spirit still lingers around the bar, maybe that is why the jukebox has never changed .. When you get the chance, check it out, the Aub Zam Zam is a great starter bar with some GOOD eye candy!
author: Tamara M.

description:
Had my first cocktail on my first date here with the bf and I think it was the secret to our success.  We were waiting to see a movie at the Vic and moised in for a cold one.  The dim lighting with the red accents did it for me, that's for sure (there is nothing more sexy then red) and there was an intangible hint of romance in the air (it also could have been something in the drinks... their mantra on their napkins: "Come, fill the cup, and in the fires of spring- the winter garments of repentance fling").   We sat in a little, secluded spot with a stiff gin & tonic and chatted, both hearts aflutter.  Things have been fabulous ever since.

I made it back in there one afternoon bc of their great 3-6pm happy hour ($2 & change well drinks!) and got the scoop from Bob.  Zam Zam was a family-run biz that opened in the 40's with an owner who was a strict 'tender that didn't take any crap.  He was notorious for throwing people out of his bar for the slightest bit of insolence.  When I was in there, some older woman attested to this bc her husband had been thrown out when he made a beeline for the jukebox before the bar!  Bob, who used to be a regular, took over to salvage the bar when the owner passed away.  The half-moon shaped bar faces an amazing mural that dates back to when it first opened and the old school ambiance is complete with an ancient cash register and a single black & white photo of women in furs and their men sitting at that very bar more than half a century ago.  It's great to find a spot in the Haight that embraces an era long before flower power... when class and charisma were all that mattered.  Thankfully, they left a little behind for us to admire
author: Tara G.

description: A tiny little mid-block hole-in-the-wall dive that fits about 20-30 patrons at a semi-circular bar and a few tables scattered around.  Its bathed in a red glow and has a vague middle eastern ambiance to it.  Quaint and intimate.
author: Rick H.

description: There is something incredibly charming about this place.  I often find myself stopping in for a quick drink after work by myself and it's great to see the locals there because they are hilarious.  It's nice and quiet most of the time, and you can have intimate conversations.  The drinks aren't memorable. They just serve your standard cocktails, but I usually only order Jameson on the rocks anyway so the only thing that matters to me where I get my libations are the ambiance.  The only downside to this place is that they don't take credit cards.
author: Jade L.

description: Very cool atmoshpere and a great jukebox. A professional older bartender.
author: Sean W.

description: I still like the Zam Zam, though I stress walking in -- too many memories.  I loved the old Persian aub Zam Zam, but it was way too stressful for me.  I mean, I always ordered gin martinis (there's no other kind), and I knew not to ask for it dry (because there's no other way), and I never even thought of asking for table service, and I tried hard to keep my voice down.  I tried very hard.  But every other time I went, it was kaputzki for me.  One time, Bruno looked at me and said, I can tell you are a good person, but your voice is too loud, so go.  (Voice?  Loud?  Moi?)  (I've entered my understated phase in recent years.)  So I'm happier now at the Zam Zam.  Pretty much.  Except for the stress.
author: Laurel B.

description: A fascinating dark room to loom in, or celebrate with a drink. The art-work and interior is beautiful, bringing vibes back from the 40's. My brother, girlfriend, and I stopped in for my brother's 21st birthday in the middle of the day to get him a drink, and both the bartender and patrons made sure that he got sloshed! It was quiet when we were there, with a very friendly crowd and an older gentleman with a knowledge of the past tending the drinks. I must say, it's just got some energy surrounding the place that makes me want to go back every day. Good thing I live in Los Angeles.  ;)
author: Shannon F.

description: One of my absolute favorite bars in this or any city. Something about it reeks of old world class. I love everything about this place, from the round, beautiful bar to the stiff drinks to the friendly / talkative / cute bartender (here's where I confess my bartender crush on Hilary). And don't even get me started on the juke box -- nothing but swing, jazz & crooners. One of the only places in this city you can go to just sit & listen to Frank Sinatra & drink a scotch or whiskey & feel right at home. The type of place that -- on the right night -- can make having a broken heart seem glamorous.
author: Pete J.

description: I love this bar. (Blink, Blink) feels like I landed inside "I dream of Jeanie's" bottle. The U shaped bar, copper colored ceiling, cinnabar red walls, and jewel toned liquour bottles in the center makes sipping a cocktails here a real full experience. Be sure to SIP the martinis here cuz they are done old school (strong.) Not too hipster, hippie, BnT, or fratboy of a crowd. Bartenders are nice as long as you're not a dithering idiot about ordering drinks.
author: Sirima S.

description: The inside of this bar is great and the music is quiet enough where you can actually hear the people you're talking to.
author: jack p.

description: One of my favorite date spots because of its old fashioned, charming, candlelit environment. It's a casual place, but if feels fancy. Maybe that's because the bartender wears spifffy clothes. Or maybe it's because the candles are always lit. They make a very tasty martini and offer garlic olives for a special twist. Good music, jazz usually, fills the air. There are lots of little tables for 2 in this smallish bar, so it's a great place to have a memorable conversation and bask in the ambiance.
author: Stumbalina b.

description: Best classic martini to enjoy ...a la film noir style with Bogart and Bacall on the brain after the Red Vic.
author: miriam b.

description: This was a great bar to end off the night... the back room has small tables where it's pretty quiet with a mellow vibe. Great martinis.
author: Andrea S.

description: Perfect place to bring a couple of friends or one very special one.  The place feels very intimate with a bar in front and some table seating towards the back.  Excellent drinks and a noise level that won't leave you with a sore throat the next day.  So glad this place opened to the public.
author: gabriella m.

description: I want to like it but why does it always smell like sick in there?? Why? And why doesn't anyone else notice?
author: D'arcy N.

description: Great semi-circular bar, for sure!  This place has the best lighting for an after dinner or after work drinking marathon in the Haight.  Hot bartenders and well-mixed cocktails.  I have also heard martini-nazi-esque stories about the owner, which I love, but have not encountered first-hand YET!  Hasn't become a place I could frequent, EVER, and I'm not sure why.  Maybe it feels a little too posh for the Haight, a little too swanky for an every day bar.  It's not really that way, it just feels that way because it's right down the street from me...  If you're coming from another area, definitely check this place out.  The inside is nice.
author: Amy M.

description: A couple of weeks ago I had to send back an undrinkable Sidecar. What a waste of beautiful alcohol, and for it to happen at my favorite local bar.  I almost cried. I have never in my life sent back a drink in ANY bar before that horrendous concoction.The place just ain't the same as it use to be. Bruno must be rolling in his grave?
author: Linsey P.

description: I dig this spot for it's retro coolness. My friends from acting class and I always hang out there on Tuesdays after class and it's usually still generally jumping.  Especially like the dark, red plush atmosphere and the jukebox is always top. Alcohol selection is so, so...but you generally go b/c it's one of the few cool places left on the Haight for a chill gathering.
author: Samira S.

description: One year, my roommate gave me a great birthday gift. We were to go to a different bar every single night of the year for the next year. He was simply disgusted that I didn't drink and didn't want to, and he thought this would force me into it. Our first stop was Aub Zam Zam, since we lived right around the corner at 710 Ashbury. The first time we went in here, the original owner (and only employee) told us to get out when we took seats in the back room. We came over to sit at the bar. We were the only customers. We ordered a vodka martini and a beer. He told us once again to GET OUT, much more forcefully. We pulled it together and each had a gin martini with a twist. The drinks were delightful and were served in beautiful crystal glasses. We befriended the owner and returned many times. We were very careful with our seating and drinks choices thereafter. Great atmosphere.
author: mary m.

description: Jack ass bartender working on Thursday evening.  Don't know the guys name, but he was a jerk who obviously suffers from low self esteem, otherwise he wouldn't treat his happy patrons that way.  It is always too bad when you want to go into an establishment and you are treated like shit.  The kind of bartender I don't want to tip.
author: Frankie S.

description: This place has character, as any place on Haight Street should. I feel cool as soon as I step in the door. The jutebox is the best in town: lots of jazz and music predating the sixties. Its cozy and a fun place to chat at the bar or just people-watch. Joe the bartender is a craftsman. If you are looking for a party, look elsewhere. If you are looking for a warm place to just be, come to AZZ.
author: Kathleen S.

description: I adore this quaint little lounge. I came in here with my sweetie to grab a drink away from the annoying crowds. Perfect choice. It was a quiet little place with a sweet bartender who was mostly busy reading her book, excellent jazz playing, and plenty of sitting room. Strong drinks and and in one word:  Classy !
author: M K.

description: Came here with my gf on a weeknight to have a few before going home. This place was probably a lot cooler back in the day, now it's filled with weird old burnt out hippies. Their liquor selection is pretty good though, I wouldn't come here to get a beer that's for sure. The ventilation system in the bathrooms could use some work.
author: Gary T.

description: Step back in time to when bars were all dark and speak-easy-ish.  Get yourself a "real" martini a la Bruno or one of them there vodker ones that's all the rage these days.  Contemplate your love of that clear, chilled, slippery fluid they so lovingly shake or stir for you, then add a tamolive and then pour in a nice vehicle for which to drown your sorrows.
author: Chard M.

description: I really love the Zam Zam. I was there when Bruno was around and I was there after he passed. Bob's a great proprietor and it's rather decadent to sit on a stool and drink an afternoon bloody mary (or "blary") at the Zam Zam as Bruno's ghost frowns at me through the mural from the great beyond.
author: Tal K.

description: I was so very sorry to hear of Bruno's passing on into the next world.  The last time I was in the bar, the manager told me and I was so sad he compted my and my friend's drinks.  That was very nice!  This is still my fav bar in the City.  Although Bruno's demise led to a slight renovation, I SO DIG the old Hollywood 1940's Persian theme.  The colors, dim lighting and the out of the way location (a 1940's bar doesn't seem to fit the stuck-in-the-60's hippy surroundings of Haight Street).  Bruno WAS a Martini-Nazi, but I never had a problem.  First time there with the boyfriend, he gave me zero attitude, and actually gladly made me a Bacardi & Coke.  I thought my boyfriend would kill me for not ordering a martini -- it always helps to have a nice rack!  :o)
author: A W.

description: The bartender/owner is the entertainment; a character out of Seinfeld, the "Martini Nazi"?  If he ever opens at all, he refuses more customers than he serves; his grumpy mutterings and exasperated gestures are sure to amuse. Seems he's been bewildered with modern life since the 60's.  Know precisely what you want to order, dress retro, talk "like a lady" and he might let you enjoy the show [oh no! other Yelp reviews say he passed on!  oh well, his ghost probably still grumbles from behind the mirror]
author: Carma K.

description:
After reading a million reviews about this bar, I was totally intrigued. apparently it used to be owned by a guy named Bruno, who was notorious for kicking people out if they ordered a drink he didn't like, or asked to have their martini served with vodka, or really for any damn reason he chose. this guy was the best bartender ever and everyone loved him. unfortunately, he passed away a few years back, so when I went to the bar a couple weeks back, there was no Bruno there. *sigh*.

walking into this bar felt like taking a step back in time. the bar itself was a very small horseshoe bar with only a few stools around it. there were a few other tiny tables, but really this place is all about sitting at the bar. I wrote earlier that the Lone Palm bar reminded me of an old movie, but this place reminded me of that even more so. light jazz was playing on the jukebox, the waiter was dressed nicely, and the place mainly served martinis. I really dug the vibe there. also, oddly enough, it also had a kind of middle eastern feel to it too.

I've never really drank martinis, but decided that I should give it a shot since I was here. it's great when you can just give the bartender free reign to make whatever they please and they invent something great for you. I hate it when you ask the bartender to recommend something, and they can't be bothered to choose a drink for you or be creative at all. the bartender at Aub Zam Zam whipped up a special martini for us made from Hendrick's gin, which is infused with rose petals and cucumbers. she also added cucumber garnish and some other stuff and the drink was really good... super refreshing. Later in the evening, we overheard her mention the "Hillary special". when we asked what that was, she said it changes from time to time, and we decided to go for it. she ended up making us two completely different drinks, one of them a sour one similar to a sidecar, and the other one was some crazy chocolate concoction. both were super good.

there was really something about this place that makes me want to go back. I so wish this could be my local neighborhood bar...

(my resolution this year is to visit 50 new bars in SF.  read about it at: http://fiftybars.thisisvlad.com)
author: vlad k.

description: I second Teddy on Mike D's performance, love him as a bartender. Always entertaining. and he is indeed good at making me virgin hot toddy's for a little switcheroo.
author: Erin O.

description: Yes, I miss the Bruno the Martini Nazi.  This place isn't quite the same without him.  When I came back in 2002, after a six year absence, I was sad to hear of his passing.
author: Al K.

description: A unique place in the Haight. Nice plush atmosphere, friendly bartenders and good company. It's a 5 star.
author: eric m.

description: The mark of a truly great bar: somewhere with a distinct theme that isn't cheesy, a mellow vibe without being boring, a place equally suited to a conversation with a friend, a nice date, or a drink with the parents.
author: Shannon R.

description:
Used to come here more often when it was less crowded. Now people have caught on and it does get a bit harder to sit down. I was in a bad mood one night and was kinda rude to some random girl, who later made me feel bad about it so I bought her and her friends drinks and felt guilty about what a schmuck I can be sometimes.. Aah, I will never learn good manners, will I?

Good place to go to if Hobsons happens to smell like puke (because someone puked) and the smell is bothering you. And, yeah - it is.
author: service p.

description: Zam Zam is an interesting Arabian nights themed deco era bar. It still retains somewhat of a speakeasy quality which is charming and unexpected considering it's grungy Upper Haight locale. The martinis continue to be very good, despite the new ownership's softening on the rules. Privately,  I think this bar far more grown up than Haight street deserves.
author: Stellah D.

description: Surprisingly (to me), I really enjoy this place. It's usually crowded, but there's a good mix of people and the bartenders are fast and nice.
author: Monika M.

description: My favorite Martini.  Nothing snobby, nothing fancy.  It is what it is and it's great.  I love the small intimate environment and having a conversation is actually possible (something I treasure in a bar).  I have been here more times than I would like to admit and it never fails.  love it!
author: Marla L.

description: I am not as in love with the atmosphere here as most people, but they know to put a cucumber in a Hendrick's martini, so they earn points with me. And the martinis are damn damn good. Damn good.
author: Lauren H.

description: Overpriced (even for touristy Haight Street) and overrated.  Tiny little bar, lackluster service, and while I'm sure they serve a mean cocktail, their beer selection leaves a lot to be desired.
author: Eric H.

description: Since my usual place is further up the street, I rarely go to other bars on Haight but M and I needed a break and so we headed here.  The bartenders were nice, the mixed drinks the right amount of strong, and the atmosphere was nice and mellow, just what we needed.
author: Pelle Y.

description: It's always nice to find a new watering hole that has a good juke box, friendly bartenders, good drinks and a nice atmosphere.  The Aladdin theme and the red walls really set the mood for a relaxing drink.
author: Corey V.

description:
When I stepped into Aub Zam Zam for the first time I never figured I would end up behind the bar that night...I went in there with my girlfriend during my month long abstaining from drinking ritual earlier this year....we were seated at the bar and the bartender (later found out he's the bar back and the bartender was late) was really overwhelmed....there were dirty glasses everywhere...and plenty of thirsty customers waiting....it took him awhile to even acknowledge our presence sitting at the bar...we waited patiently and he finally served us...i ordered a coke and my girlfriend had a beer....he went on to tell us that they are out of syrup and gas for the sodas so he couldn't serve any mixed drinks through the gun....he didn't know how to fix it either....so i told him that i knew how change them so i jumped behind the bar and fixed the sodas and the gas and saved the day!!!...he bought our drinks and then he continued to serve those thirsty patrons....
Their jukebox is pretty good and they also have an atm for those plastic wielding folks....
author: D J.

description: Great atmosphere. A great place to chill out and drink. There's nearly zero cell phone reception, for better or for worse.
author: Michael H.

description: I have yet to try the infamous martinis here, but love the ambience.  It is so wonderful to find chill bars in the city, where people are mellow and the vibe is cool.  Had a fun little corner of the bar with friends for a nice mid-week birthday celebration.  Can't wait to go back for martinis :-)
author: Jamie E.

description:
my favorite place in sf for mojitos..

i do have to agree that the older gentleman that's there during the daytime makes the best mojitos..  i went in one night and they weren't very good, but commented the next time i saw the daytime bartender, and they have been great ever since.

great jukebox: 
billie holiday
hank williams
ray charles
etta james
thelonious monk
and the like..

beautiful bar and mural.  no beer on tap.  free pretzels in the daytime.  parking's pretty easy to find at nighttime (for me anyway).

1 star deduction for the cold water in the bathrooms and pink dishwashing liquid for handsoap, and no pretzels at night time  :(
author: Kimby T.

description: The decor here is super cool, even in the mens room!  Drinks are strong and old fashioned, definitely poured with a heavy hand.  The martinis here are awesome and the random conversations that I have fell upon in this place are unreal.  Certainly a real classic upper haight bar.  Pretty much a legend amongst san franciscos drunkard elite!
author: Francis K.

description: Someone told me about this retro place months ago and it slipped my mind to go there, until one day I was on the 71 bus and saw it.  I got off the bus and went in.  Was I pleasantly surprised!  Great retro bar!  And . . . best of all . . . NO TV!  I really liked the 40's music playing on their sound system!  Bartender I met, was very nice.  Great crowd.  I'd recommend it to anyone who likes retro bars.
author: Ray K.

description: Zam Zam is the oldest and coolest bar I've ever been to! Even the register on the bar has been there since the 50's! Great music and the best martinis! The bar is small and very intimate, great place to meet people...
author: Jessica C.

description: Love the decor of this place with its plush chairs, and the drink selection ain't too shabby either.  Come by on an evening when it's not too crowded and you'll have a blast.  This is definitely the type of place to start your bar-hopping night.
author: Paul H.

description:
In the mid 90's my room-mates and I lived on the corner of Haight and Ashbury, above Ardvarks used clothing store.  We used to go to club delux a lot, gold cane and Aub Zam Zam.  I went to AZZ 5 times in about 4 years.  I was thrown out the first 4 times by the old guy who I never really met...

odd...

and I was only served a drink twice.  Still, somehow, I wanted to go in and be served by the owner who either didn't want to be there or didn't want me to be there.  The last time I was there, the owner said we were laughing too loud.  So he turned the music up REALLY loud, then he turned the music off.  He turned off the lights and walked out the back.  Left us there, in the dark.  With another couple sitting there.  Who'duv thought?  Some one mentioned to me he passed away.  Somehow sad.
author: Christopher C.

description: Another bar that my old roommate took us to and another winner.  The half-circle bar was a nice touch, the bartender poured us some very strong drinks that were reasonably priced, and we eventually took over half the small back room.  Later in the night, two of my friends brought their dogs in to say hello and the bartender just smiled.  Love it.
author: Lady T.

description: Okay atmosphere, weak drinks (despite a nice tip beforehand).
author: Mike W.

description: I can't stay away from this place. It feels like Cheers to me. There are always interesting characters to talk to and the bar tenders are super friendly. I always feel welcome here and you will too.
author: Kerry W.

description: Not as good as when Bruno was dispensing insults and martinis, but surprisingly not terrible either. The space remains really great and drinks are still stiff and good.
author: Andrew L.

description: This place is cozy with fun drinks.  it's hip without being pretentious.  I would say the drinks are stronger than average and the music is usually pretty good. The bartenders are friendly and I really enjoy sitting up at the bar. Would drink here again.
author: Jessica T.

description: This is a great place to escape the craziness of the outside world and enjoy a great martini, or two, or three...
author: R T.

description:
While the Aub Zam Zam is a historical relic worth of a visit.. it is but a pale imitation of it's former glory under the auspices of Bruno.. the late proprieter.. when he was open, the doors were closed, and one had to enter his domain with a push on the famous door.. there are many historical inaccuracies connected with the zam zam.. and to go there now without knowing the actual history is to watch television in a tour bus while on a trip in Egypt to the Valley of the Kings.. a previous reviewer, SSJ, summed it up very well.. "Alright. I worked at zam zam for five years. There is basically no truth to the myth that ordering a martini was a requirement to sit at the bar. What is true is that Bruno would not make trendy, labor intensive drinks (no mojitos, cosmos or appletinis). What is also true is that the jukebox may be one of the best in town, the locals are some of the kindest people I've ever met and late at night I can assure you Bruno still haunts the joint. "

When I was a customer in the mide and late 1960's, Bruno was a good proprietor, with some rules.. yes.. but then, not the way he is portrayed now.. my first order was a Singapore Sling.. and Bruno made the best I ever had.. and the jukebox contained then big band sounds.. the favorite that I played on every visit was 'American Patrol' by Glen Miller.. yes, Bruno would prevent entry to those he deemed not worthy.. but, then, they were all people that I personally would not want in my house.. May he Rest in Peace, and may some of those who enter his former place of business know something of the man.. a WWII veteran making his way in the world with class..

as for the 'new' place.. well, as far as it goes.. ok.. but nowhere near the vivid ambiancecontained in the past...
author: Phillip D.

description: Practically invisible from the street, Aub Zam Zam is surprisingly cute inside.  A very nice horse-shoe-shaped bar with an interesting, bizarre and unsettling mural behind, and several small tables against the walls are the only occupants of this little place.  Though well lit, the interior is looking a little shabby, and there was a pervasive funky odor more suited to a dive bar, which this place is striving hard not to be.  The juke box is decent, though, and the bartender who waited on us (didn't catch his name) was excellent.  Downsides: no food, cash only.  Great place to catch up with a friend for a pre-dinner drink.
author: Kirsten K.

description: This place is my fav hang out for 2 reasons.  One, I feel at home amongst the slightly decaying 50's style décor and two, it is with in walking distance of my house.  I am not super sure how to rate bars since I don't frequent a huge variety but the clientele are fun and the bartenders nice.  It is a place me, and my fedora, always feel welcome.  Give it a try.  You might like what you see.
author: Amy P.

description: Went here last nite and the bartender made the worst martini that I can remember, of course I was pretty tossed at this point. But I can still taste the Vermouth, Maybe she forgot to add the booze.  I been before and had well made drinks here. I don't know if ill be back though.
author: jo m.

description: Went because they were advertising  $2 PBR and we were looking for a cheap place to drink after Outside Lands-the sign even said "welcome outsidelandians". A tweaker walked by saying "it's a trap, don't go in!" while we were deciding. Ordered beers and waters, bartender checks IDs and give us 2 PBRs (in bottles no less?). We were enjoying the back area and commenting how we liked the bar-confused about the bottles, but got up to go smoke, and the bartender yells at us for bringing beer in. We laughed, thought he was joking, but they were yelling, grabbed me by the arm and threw us out-saying we brought the beers in. We clearly did not. I know I am from out off town, but I just don't get it. Should have taken that guy's advice I guess.
author: tichelle c.

description: Im in love with this place - to coin a phrase "bloody awesome"
author: Stuart g.

description: We went here after a long bike ride and it was the perfect afternoon drink spot.  The bar is set up in a horseshoe with the bartender in the middle.  Once your glass is empty the bartender responds with another perfect beverage!!!
author: Andrea H.

description: i don't get out to this area much but stopped in for a drink last weekend before meeting up at a friends house-- i really liked this bar. it was well before the 'bewitching hour' so the bar was sort of empty but it had a comfortable feel and good service. i would love to go back again and see what the crowd is like and check out that amusing bartender someone mentioned.
author: Michelle I.

description: My husband and I stumbled in here on a recent Sunday at around 5:00 pm. We were walking down Haight, just killing time before meeting someone for dinner when we decided we wanted a drink. I was craving a beer, so I was a little annoyed when my husband pulled me into Zam Zam. I was in kind of a bad mood, so I ordered a beer just to prove my point. I soon regreted that. The friendly bartender gave me a menu and I started drooling over the martinis after only one sip of my Sierra Nevada. Watching the bartender make them intensified my craving...she looked very skilled. My husband ordered a dirty martini, but I didn't just because it was Sunday and I had my first day of my new job the next day....didn't want to get too wasted. However, I sampled his and it was AWESOME. I definitely want to go back and try the martini made with pomegranate vodka. The decor is really cool, too...I think it's supposed to be Moroccan.
author: Jenny R.

description: Went to the original zam zam's. Had a drink there with a friend. The martini's were just ok. Then the bartender shorted me on my change. Won't go back there again.
author: c w.

description: not the friendliest place in the world but the bartender wears a vest and tie and makes a really good manhattan.  the well bourbon ain't that bad either.
author: Markus B.

description: It's a chic place and I love the retro feel.  It's kind of odd to find it in the Haight but it's a nice retreat
author: Misti L.

description:
the drinks are strong, the bar folks are crazy and the walls are red. it all adds up to: a kick ass place to get trashed...

also, the haight street crowd adds a dimension of interest. whatever  else the  bar may be, one thing's fersure: its never dull!
author: Pia C.

description: definitely a favorite of mine. well, okay, not necessarily a favorite, but a trusty old stand-by.
author: Joanna R.

description: aub zam zam is cool little spot i went in to last night on haight.  it's a dive with no taps and a strage beer selection.  no miller lite?  strange.  the bartender was eastern european and couldn't really speak great english.  she didn't seem like much of a bartender to me (i've been to europe and they are terrible bartenders over there).  however, she was nice.  i ordered a beer and a shot.  it didn't break the bank.  i don't have much to say other than, it's a cool little dive on haight and i would go back.
author: T D.

description: as a martini drinker and jazz fan, this became my local within days of moving to the haight. i like it so much that we created our own version at burningman 06. get yourself some hendrick's if you drink the gin.
author: Clover Dan ..

description: It's so funny that someone mentioned the smell in this bar.  Every time I used to go in there it smelled bad...though I have been told that I have over-active olfactory senses...but I always thought that was just what stinky people told me to cover their stinky tracks.  The smell always saddened me because I really enjoyed the atmosphere of this place.  But I went back last weekend, warning my guest about the potential odor, and to my pleasant surprise, the smell was gone!  Thus, sans stanky scent, this is a great little neighborhood establishment.  The drinks are just the right strength.  The barkeep is always friendly and wears that cool, old-school 70's barkeep garb.  It's a perfect place to grab a drink and have good conversation while you wait for a table at Cha Cha Chas:)
author: Marie M.

description: We had a great time at this bar last night, can't put my finger on why but would definitely recommend giving it a try. We were trying to figure out where to go after a slightly-less-than-fabulous experience at Alembic, and stumbled in here. We hadn't been yet, and weren't sure if it was what we were looking for, but once we'd ducked in, our friend saw someone she knew, so we came on in. And we were happy we did! Good selection of spirits, friendly bartender, good company, funky little vibe, fun random jukebox. A couple of drinks later - when of course we'd gone in "just for one," as always - we remembered we had to call it a night early, it being a Wednesday, and me having a big day at work the next day, but I'd be more than happy to come back next time I'm in this 'hood. Not sure if I'd cab it over to the Haight just to go here, but I could have closed the place last night for sure, and it's definitely one of the better new bar experiences I've had for a while for some reason! Check it out if you're on Haight in need of a drink.
author: Sarah R.

description: great old school appeal.  old school jukebox, old school menu, old school decor-one of the only accurate islamic inspired venues i have seen. old school service.  real bartenders, but the real attitude to match it sometimes.  the drinks are stiff in a 1950's housewife sort of way.  perfect for afternoon drunks.  its kind of surprising that its even on haight st.  belongs in polk gulch or tucked in a back corner of north beach or even lower haight.
author: Christian W.

description: it's a cute little bar! the bartenders are quick. perfect for a few friends grabbing drinks, catching up. maybe not a huge group, though.
author: Rosalee C.

description: this place is good when it's not crowded. and this place is good when it is crowded. what can i say, i like the tiny space, close quarters, little tables, and liquor!!
author: Sprout S.

description: i always have the weirdest conversations with people when I come here. this is total haight fixture now - kinda like the stripper store. very nice persian style motif & lots of good intimate seating. take someone you like here, have a junipero & tonic with your weird conversation.
author: Lawrence K.

description: Nice to see the Zam Zam room is still alive...seems to have been "democratized" after Bruno went to the great hereafter.  Now the odds on being served are much better than the 1/10 you faced years ago if a) you weren't Herb Caen or b) weren't dressed up.
author: Ay S.

description: This small dive on haight is often overlooked by those passing by but if happen to catch a red glow at the corner of your eye it will be well worth turning your head and going in . . . especially if you are on a date. The bar is part of San Francisco history and urban folklore and has been around for decades. The previous owner nicknamed "the martini nazi" used to kick people out if he didn't like you or order in a certain way . . .luckily it is under new ownership and the small bar capable of perhaps seating no more than 20 is a popular destination for young professionals and even the occasional writers groups. The bartenders there are extremely laid back and friendly and make a mean martini.
author: Sequoia N.

description: Not a fan of the fashion first Upper Haight, but thanks to this place and a certain bartender i am some sort of regular. the whole damn staff is great  and it's always fun meeting other regulars and hanging out with random people from all in the world that came to see what it was like in the "hippy days" and score shitty weed  from those foul smelling fuckers in the park. the decor is nice especially that little stand that has a black top, in the right light it looks like a trash can and it was hella funny watching my boy throw trash onto it and wondering why it wasn't going in. dumb ass ha. check it out when your in the hood.
author: Ausewaldoe J.

description: i like this place, can't think of a specific quality that makes it stand out. it is intimate, with a dim red sheen around the cavelike entrance, there is 1920's jazz playing in the backround.  tiny rounded tables for talking and/or giggling, damn good 7and 7's. the bartenders know what they are doing, so trust them. my writing group used to meet here, this bar has a sophisticated,scholarly feel without seeming pretentious. equally good for scribbling away in your journal, or flirting at the bar.
author: Lesley S.
